Resumo

O rifte do Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? (RTJ) conte?m o registro da porc?a?o abortada de um

sistema de bacias distensivas formadas do Juro-Creta?ceo ao Aptiano no leste da Ame?rica do

Sul. Nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte compreende ambientes deposicionais lacustres,

eo?licos, deltaicos e aluviais, previamente interpretados como depositados ao longo dos

esta?gios de subside?ncia pre?-, sin- e po?s-rifte. Cada ambiente destes foi estudado na escala

da bacia, o que permitiu a identificac?a?o de alvos para prospecc?a?o de petro?leo, em especial

na Bacia do Reco?ncavo. Contudo, poucos estudos abordaram a descric?a?o detalhada de

afloramentos, o que limita a compreensa?o de processos com escalas temporais menores de

unidades estudadas em subsuperf??cie. Esse e? o caso da Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o, depositada

entre o Barremiano e o Neocomiano, e da Formac?a?o Marizal, depositada no Aptiano.

Ambas constituem sistemas aluviais com ampla expressa?o nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central

e Norte, onde esta?o localizados o maior depocentro do rifte, denominado de Baixo de C??cero

Dantas, e a Zona de Transfere?ncia do Vaza Barris, caracterizada como um alto estrutural.

Essas duas feic?o?es sa?o resultado de diferentes taxas de subside?ncia na Bacia do Tucano, e

por isso servem para testar a sensibilidade de sistemas fluviais a controles tecto?nicos.

Nesse sentido, os depo?sitos de cada a?rea foram estudados em detalhe atrave?s de me?todos

de ana?lises de fa?cies, elementos arquiteturais, paleocorrentes e provenie?ncia, o que permitiu

interpretar estilos fluviais contrastantes. Na a?rea pro?xima ao eixo das sub-bacias, a

arquitetura da Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o e? semelhante a de rios entrelac?ados arenosos, e na

porc?a?o leste a? de rios de carga mista, o que confirma a hipo?tese de que controles tecto?nicos

diferenciados podem resultar em mudanc?as na arquitetura deposicional. Na primeira,

foram interpretados cinco elementos arquiteturais, dentre os quais predominam barras

unita?rias ou dunas grandes e compostas (EA1) e barras de acre?scimo a jusante (EA2), sendo

menos frequentes elementos de preenchimento de canais pequenos (EA3), dunas eo?licas

(EA4) e depo?sitos de topo de barras (EA5). A abunda?ncia do elemento de barras unita?rias

ou dunas grandes e compostas, com espessuras me?dias superiores a 1 m e ma?ximas de 5

m e? considerada como evide?ncia da presenc?a de canais profundos na regia?o, o que sugere a

existe?ncia de um sistema fluvial de grandes proporc?o?es, que na?o apresentava modificac?o?es

na arquitetura entre a?reas dentro da pro?pria zona de transfere?ncia. A distinc?a?o entre os

elementos EA1 e EA2 pode ser utilizada na documentac?a?o de rios de grande porte e servir

como complemento aos conceitos utilizados em estudos de sistemas fluviais.

Na a?rea pro?xima ao Baixo de C??cero Dantas foram identificados elementos diagno?sticos

de dois ambientes do sistema fluvial: (1) canais, caracterizados pela ocorre?ncia de barras



unita?rias e dunas grandes e compostas, barras de acre?scimo a jusante e preenchimento de

canal pequeno; (2) a?reas ale?m das margens do canal principal, caracterizadas por depo?sitos

de dunas eo?licas, plan??cie ou bacias de inundac?a?o, canal abandonado e leque de rompimento

de dique marginal. A alterna?ncia entre estes ambientes e? interpretada como decorrente de

altas taxas de subside?ncia, o que teria favorecido a preservac?a?o de plan??cies de inundac?a?o

associadas ao sistema fluvial local, onde estas taxas sa?o as maiores do sistema RTJ e esta?o

preservados 14 km de sucesso?es sin-rifte.

Estudos detalhados de provenie?ncia de seixos e calhaus, integrados a dados de

paleocorrente, revelaram reduc?a?o abrupta de maturidade mineralo?gica na passagem

entre os depo?sitos fluviais Barremiano-Neocomianos e Aptianos. Como forma de

entender essa mudanc?a abrupta foram propostos dois esta?gios evolutivos: (1) durante o

Neocomomiano-Barremiano predominava um sistema fluvial axial ao rifte, que flu??a para

sul e transportava em sua maioria clastos de retrabalhamento polic??clico de sucesso?es

paleozoicas e mesozoicas aflorantes nas ombreiras e a norte a partir de uma bacia de

captac?a?o regional responsa?vel pela denudac?a?o das a?reas em soerguimento durante a

distensa?o do per??odo; (2) durante o Aptiano, manteve-se o sistema fluvial axial com

fluxo me?dio para sul, pore?m com grande variabilidade de clastos e menor freque?ncia de

polic??clicos, o que sugere fontes do embasamento Pre?-Cambriano provenientes de leste e

oeste. Este cena?rio e? indicativo de que a falha de borda esteve ativa e causou o soerguimento

de rochas do embasamento durante a deposic?a?o da Formac?a?o Marizal, contrapondo

interpretac?o?es anteriores segundo as quais esta pertenceria a fase de subside?ncia te?rmica da

bacia. A presenc?a de falhas normais e obl??quas nessa unidade na Sub-Bacia Tucano Norte

e a similaridade entre os clastos encontrados na Formac?a?o Marizal e nos leques aluviais a

leste reforc?am o modelo em que e? proposto o soerguimento do embasamento ate? o n??vel

das ombreiras do rifte, que passaria a ter suas fontes paleozoicas e mesozoicas localizadas

atra?s de um divisor de a?guas.

Desta forma, o sistema fluvial da Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o pode ser caracterizado como

resultante da presenc?a de um rio de grandes proporc?o?es no eixo de uma das principais

bacias rifte do Eocreta?ceo brasileiro. Este sistema esteve relacionado, possivelmente, a

uma bacia de captac?a?o regional, que apesar do grande fluxo sedimentar, apresentava taxas

localmente altas de subside?ncia, como na regia?o do Baixo de C??cero Dantas, o que favoreceu

as modificac?o?es locais ocorridas na arquitetura deposicional. As a?reas-fonte deste sistema

foram predominantemente sucesso?es sedimentares paleozoicas e mesozoicas, presentes em

toda regia?o e dominantes nas ombreiras da bacia ate? o Barremiano. Reativac?a?o tecto?nica



da bacia e soerguimento renovado das ombreiras apo?s o recuo erosivo das escarpas de

rochas mesozoicas e paleozoicas marca um aumento expressivo na contribuic?a?o de rochas

do embasamento nas sucesso?es Aptianas sobrepostas.



Abstract

The Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? rift (RTJ) contains the record of an aborted branch

of a system of extensional basins formed from the Jurassic-Cretaceous boundary up

to the Aptian, in eastern South America. In the Central and Northern Tucano

Sub-Basins, this record comprehends mostly lacustrine, eolian, deltaic and alluvial

depositional environments, previously interpreted as the deposits of pre-, syn- and post-rift

subsidence stages. Each system has been studied at the basin scale, which has enabled

the identification of targets for oil exploration, particularly in the Reco?ncavo Basin.

Nevertheless, few previous works deal with the detailed description of outcrops, limiting the

comprehension of the processes operating at smaller temporal scales in the units studied

in the subsurface. That is the case of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation, deposited between

Neocomian and Barremian, and of the Marizal Formation, deposited in the Aptian. Both

units are composed of alluvial systems with widespread occurrence in the Central and

Northern Tucano Sub-Basins, where are located the major depocenter of the rift (C??cero

Dantas Low) and the Vaza Barris Transfer Zone, characterized as a structural high. These

two structures are the result of different subsidence rates, and therefore enable to evaluate

the hypothesis concerning the tectonic controls on fluvial sedimentation.

Following this approach, deposits of these different areas were studied through the

analysis of lithofacies, architectural elements, paleocurrents and provenance, leading to

the interpretation of contrasting fluvial styles. In the axis of the Central and Northern

Tucano Sub-Basins, the architecture of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation is similar to that of

sandy braided rivers, while in the eastern part of the basin, the architecture resembles

mixed-load rivers, pointing to a tectonic control for each different depositional architecture

observed. Five architectural elements were identified in the axis of the central area, with

the dominance of unit bars or large compound dunes (AE1) and downstream accretion

compound bars (AE2), and subordinated occurrence of minor channel fills (AE3), eolian

dunes (AE4) and bar top deposits (AE5). The abundance of the unit bars or large

compound dunes element with the thickness of individual sets reaching 1 to 5 m thick is

considered as evidence for the dominance of deep fluvial channels in the region, suggesting

a fluvial system of large dimensions with no significant variation in architecture in the area

of the Vaza Barris transfer zone. The distinction between the elements EA1 and EA2 can

be applied in the recognition of big river deposits and complement the current concepts

used in the study of fluvial deposits.

In the deposits found near the C??cero Dantas Low, elements diagnostic of two



environments within the fluvial system were identified: (1) deposits of the channel belt

(unit bars and large compound dunes, downstream accretion bars, and minor channel fills),

and (2) deposits of overbank areas (eolian dunes, floodplains or floodbasins, abandoned

channels, and crevasse splays). The vertical recurrence of these two environments is

interpreted as a result of high subsidence rates, which would have favored the preservation

of floodplains in the local fluvial system, where the subsidence rates were the highest in

the whole RTJ, locally preserving up to 14 km of syn-rift successions.

Detailed studies on the provenance of pebbles and cobbles revealed an abrupt reduction

in the compositional maturity at the passage between the Neocomian and the Aptian

successions. A two-stage scenario is proposed to explain this abrupt change: (1) during

the Neocomian-Barremian a fluvial system axial to the rift structure flowed towards the

south and transported mainly polyciclically reworked clasts from paleozoic and mesozoic

successions that cropped out at the basin shoulder and to the north, in a regional catchment

area responsible for the denudation of the areas that were being uplifted during the regional

extensional event; (2) during the Aptian, this fluvial system was still flowing towards the

south, but nevertheless carrying a much varied composition of clasts, with markedly lower

content of polyciclically reworked clasts, suggesting a greater contribution of Precambrian

basement sources from the east and west. This scenario is indicative that the basin-border

fault was active and caused the uplift of the basement rocks during the deposition of the

Marizal Formation, in opposition to previous interpretations according to which the unit

would be related to the thermal subsidence phase of the basin. The presence of normal

and oblique faults in the Northern Tucano Sub-Basin and the similarity between the clast

composition of the Marizal Formation and the alluvial fan deposits to the east corroborate

the model, with the uplift of the basement to the level of the basin shoulders, and the

location of the paleozoic and mesozoic sources behind a watershed.

Therefore, the fluvial system fill of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation in the Central Tucano

Sub-Basin was interpreted as a result of the installation of a big river system on the axis of

one of the major rift basins of the Early Cretaceous in Brazil. The older fluvial system (Sa?o

Sebastia?o Formation) is possibly related to a regional catchment, despite the great sediment

flux to the basin, local high rates of subsidence, as in the region of the C??cero Dantas Low,

resulted in local modifications in the architecture of the deposits, with greater preservation

of floodplain and bar top facies. The source areas of this system were mainly paleozoic and

mesozoic sedimentary successions, present in the whole region and dominant at the basin

shoulders up to the Barremian. Tectonic activation of the basin and renewed uplift of the



basin shoulders after the erosional retreat of the scarps of mesozoic and paleozoic rocks is

evidenced by an expressive increase in the contribution of basement rocks in the Aptian

succession.

23 Part three and four of five (lower rectangle) of the interpreted photomosaic from

bounded by increment surfaces – 4 indicates a gradual decrease of water depth,

association of elements is the direct passage from large-scale unit bars to eolian

28 Interpreted photomosaic (site 6, see Fig. 20) of the crevasse splay wedge (AE7)

over flood-plain deposits (AE5) indicating a paleoflow towards south (left). The

crevasse splay deposit is bounded at the bottom by an irregular floodplain basal

surface (8) dipping south. The person for scale is 1.75 m tall. The systematic

abrupt superimposition of floodplain fines and Eolian dunes over Unit Bars with

large-scale cross-bedding formed in the deep parts of channels (Fig. 23 – Part

4) is interpreted as the result of higher hank surfaces than those due to bar-top

erosion, possibly related to channel avulsion (e.g. Jones Haje, 2007). This suggests

that the deposition of floodplain fines are not necessarily related to the accretion of

smaller-scale bedforms that migrated over larger host bedforms and were preserved

in the form of bar-top deposits in the sense of Best et al. (2006). Additionally,

the onlap pattern, which indicates the erosion of the previously deposited bar

succession, later overlain by flood-plain fines in the oppose angle of migration

against the floodplain basal surface (Figs. 23, 24, 30) is more consistent with the

avulsion of the main channel, which would create an isolated environment, more

susceptible to the preservation of mud and sandy-silt particles deposits than at the

bar top. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 106

1. Introduc?a?o

Durante a Era Mesozo?ica, a configurac?a?o dos blocos que constitu??am a porc?a?o oeste

do continente Gondwana foi gradativamente modificada por meio da atuac?a?o de esforc?os

distensivos, que culminaram com sua ruptura durante o Creta?ceo (Asmus, 1984). O

processo de distensa?o permitiu a formac?a?o de crosta ocea?nica e a abertura da parte sul

do atual oceano Atla?ntico, originando as placas Sulamericana e Africana, bem como suas

bacias marginais (e.g. Potiguar, Sergipe-Alagoas, Campos, Santos). Ainda nesse per??odo,

a deformac?a?o distensiva entre os atuais Estados da Bahia e Pernambuco deu origem a

bacias intra-continentais, com magmatismo muito restrito, por vezes, preservadas como

riftes abortados. Neste contexto, os segmentos Norte e Central da Bacia do Tucano,

localizados na regia?o nordeste dos Estados da Bahia e oeste dos Estados de Pernambuco,

Sergipe e Alagoas, representam a porc?a?o Central de um rifte abortado, denominado

Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? (RTJ).

Ate? o momento, pesquisas sobre a geologia estrutural (e.g. Milani & Davison, 1988;

Magnavita et al., 1994; Destro, 2002), ana?lise estratigra?fica de testemunhos de sondagem

(Netto et al., 1984) e modelagem matema?tica do Rifte RTJ e da Bacia marginal

Sergipe-Alagoas (Karner et al., 1992) voltadas a? prospecc?a?o de petro?leo em subsuperf??cie,

levaram a modelos sobre a evoluc?a?o do rifte em escala regional (Magnavita et al., 1994).

Embora estas bacias sejam discutidas por va?rios autores (e.g. Ussami et al., 1986;

Castro Jr, 1987; Milani & Davison, 1988), que as interpretaram como parte do mesmo

sistema de rifte, estudos sedimentolo?gicos em escala de afloramento sa?o ainda escassos

(Gontijo, 1988; Feijo?, 1994; Arienti, 1996), principalmente, nos segmentos Central e Norte

da Bacia do Tucano. Em geral, as pesquisas na regia?o abordaram descric?o?es puramente

litoestratigra?ficas, com enfoque nos aspectos texturais e sedimentolo?gicos de cada unidade

(Viana et al., 1971; Netto & Oliveira, 1985; Castro Jr, 1987; Caixeta et al., 1994), pore?m

com menor freque?ncia na interpretac?a?o de paleoambientes (e.g. Garcia, 1991). Publicac?o?es

mais recentes mostraram a integrac?a?o de novos dados de poc?os explorato?rios e de estudos

s??smicos (Magnavita et al., 2003; Costa et al., 2003, 2007), que corroboram em parte a

estratigrafia e os sistemas deposicionais descritos anteriormente para estas sub-bacias.

Desta forma, para explorar a questa?o do desenvolvimento de sistemas deposicionais e

do preenchimento sedimentar em bacias tipo rifte, pouco discutido sob o ponto de vista

da arquitetura deposicional em escala de afloramento (e.g. Feijo?, 1994; Arienti, 1996),

foram realizados estudos de campo nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte, com foco

na sedimentac?a?o aluvial da Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o e nos controles tecto?nicos atuantes



14

durante sua deposic?a?o e a da Formac?a?o Marizal sobrejacente.

Do ponto de vista dos modelos de evoluc?a?o de sistemas fluviais em contextos

tectonicamente ativos, as sucesso?es expostas nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte sa?o de

grande interesse, principalmente pela abunda?ncia de exposic?o?es com grande continuidade

lateral. Desta forma, a presente tese parte de algumas questo?es principais:

• Ha? variac?o?es de estilos fluviais e da geometria deposicional entre a?reas de maior e
menor subside?ncia das Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte?

• A arquitetura deposicional dos depo?sitos fluviais e? influenciada pela Zona de
Transfere?ncia do Vaza Barris nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte?

• Como evolu??ram as a?reas-fonte e as bacias de captac?a?o de drenagem durante o
preenchimento da Bacia do Tucano entre o Neocomiano-Barremiano e o Aptiano?

• Qual a escala do sistema fluvial depositado nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte
durante o Neocomiano-Barremiano?

• As ferramentas conceituais dispon??veis para o estudo de arquitetura deposicional de
sistemas fluviais em escala de afloramento sa?o adequadas para a caracterizac?a?o de

rios de grande porte?

De forma a obter um aprofundamento nessas questo?es, a presente tese e? estruturada

em duas partes: (1) reviso?es teo?ricas e conceituais sobre os temas pertinentes, incluindo

controles tecto?nicos sobre a sedimentac?a?o fluvial em bacias rifte, modelos pre?vios sobre

tecto?nica e sedimentac?a?o no rifte RTJ; (2) resultados obtidos, organizados em tre?s artigos.

de detalhe, dentro das quais representam sua menor parte. Os intervalos que as separam

6. Resultados

Os resultados da tese seguem na forma de artigos:

6.1. Artigo 1 – Distinguishing large mesoforms from

(Early Cretaceous, Northeastern Brazil): implications for

the recognition of ancient big rivers

- submetido ao Journal of Sedimentary Research.

ABSTRACT

Big rivers are a major element in the dynamics of the Earth surface and potentially

represent a great proportion of the preserved fluvial record. Nevertheless, the scarcity of

studies on the depositional architecture of modern and ancient large rivers, which demand

suitable exposures, are responsible for the lack of specific facies models and of clearly

defined criteria for the recognition of large fluvial systems. The well exposed Tucano

Basin, in Northeastern Brazil, comprises Neocomian to Barremian fluvial successions

characterized by abundant large-scale cross-strata in pebbly sandstones. The recognition

of sandstone elements bounded by climbing surfaces and internally composed of large-scale

cross-strata and compound cross-strata led to the interpretation of an origin in the

migration of several meters high unit bars or compound dunes. The dominance of

this architectural element is indicative of several meters deep fluvial channels. The

recognition of similar architecture in other fluvial systems may be used as criteria for

the characterization of ancient large rivers, even where partial preservation of bedforms

results in thinner cross-strata sets.



54

INTRODUCTION

Big rivers are the most important routes of sediment into modern oceans (e.g. Potter,

1978; Tandon Sinha, 2007; Moore et al. 2007) and are defined on the basis of drainage

area, channel length, and water and sediment discharge (Hovius, 1998). Criteria for the

recognition of large rivers in the rock record include channel depth, both observed and

interpreted from preserved thickness of mesoform cross-strata, cross-sectional width of

channel sediment bodies, scale of macroforms and megaforms (sensu Jackson, 1976; Church

and Jones, 1982) and longevity of the river system (Fielding, 2007). The identification of

big rivers, and especially the recognition of channel scale in the rock record, requires

large and continuous exposures in varied orientations (Bridge, 2006). Nevertheless, despite

the recognition of some degree of scale invariance in braided rivers (Best et al., 2003;

Sambrook-Smith et al., 2005), the direct application of methods of hierarchical ordering

of surfaces and classification of architectural elements developed for small rivers can be

misleading. One obvious problem arises from the fact that mesoforms in large rivers

developed during high-stage can be larger and taller than the macroforms in smaller rivers.

In this situation, the distinction between inclined cross-sets formed by compound bar

growth from those formed by migration of compound dunes or unit bars of similar scale

can be critical in the interpretation of large river deposits.

The present work brings examples of architectural elements of unit bars and large

compound dunes from the well exposed Neocomian to Barremian Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation

in the Tucano Basin, Northeastern Brazil (Fig. 10), and discusses their implication to the

hierarchical ordering of bounding surfaces in fluvial deposits and to the characterization of

deposits of big rivers.

GEOLOGICAL SETTING

The Tucano Basin is located in Northeastern Brazil and comprises the major area of

the Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? rift system (RTJ) (Fig. 10). It has an area of approximately

30,500 km2, with a mean E-W width of 80 km and approximately 400 km in N-S length.

The larger axis of the basin is cut by NW-SE-oriented transfer zones (Milani Davison,

1988), which divide the basin in three separate sub-basins – the South, Central and North

Tucano. The South and Central sub-basins are limited by the Itapicuru transfer zone,

whereas the Central and North sub-basins are separated by the Vaza Barris transfer zone

(VBTZ) (Fig 10). The master faults of the northern and central Tucano sub-basins are



55

Figura 10. Geological map of the Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? (RTJ) Rift and its adjacent basement rocks,
highlighting the outcrops of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation. Figure modified from Magnavita (1996), Barbosa
and Sabate? (2004) and Gava et al. 1983.



56

opposed to each other, dipping respectively to E-SE and W-NW. The RTJ is an aborted

branch of the Early Cretaceous rift system that resulted in the opening of the South

Atlantic (e.g. Milani Davison, 1988; Magnavita, 1992; Milani Thomaz Filho, 2002). The

regional tectonic activation responsible for rifting in eastern South America also lead to

the uplift of the Precambrian basement and of the Paleozoic to Mesozoic deposits of sag

basins. While most of the rift basins of the system record lacustrine facies during the Early

Cretaceous, a long lasting, locally south-flowing river system was captured into the Tucano

Basin. As a result the fluvial succession of the basin can be more than 3,000 m thick and

spans up to 30 million years (including the Aptian Marizal Formation). The fill of the RTJ

basins is usually divided in four depositional sequences ascribed to pre-, syn- and post-rift

stages (e.g. Magnavita et al, 2003, Silva et al., 2007, Costa et al., 2007a, Costa et al 2007b).

The rifting-related sedimentary units in the RTJ comprise, from base to top, lacustrine

shales (Candeias Formation), deltaic sandstones and mudstones (Ilhas Group), and fluvial

sandstones (Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation), in a typical progradational architecture. All of the

above mentioned units are laterally related to alluvial fan conglomerates and sandstones

(Salvador Formation). The age of the syn-rift phase in the RTJ is currently constrained

between the Berriasian, at around 144 Ma, and the Early Aptian, at around 124 Ma (e.g.

Milani et al., 2007). The structural highs related to the Itapicuru and Vaza Barris transfer

zones seem to have acted as topographic barriers up to the Valanginian (Magnavita and

Cupertino, 1987).

METHODS

The analysis of the architecture of fluvial deposits from the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formaiton

was performed in seven outcrops located in the Vaza Barris transfer zone, mostly in

the northern part of the Central Tucano sub-basin. Rock exposures of up to 40 m in

height and several hundred meters long were subject to facies and architectural element

analysis (e.g. Reading, 1986, Walker, 1992, Miall, 1990, Miall, 1996 and Miall, 2000).

Columnar stratigraphic sections and outcrop maps based on photomosaics were elaborated

to represent the vertical and lateral distribution of lithofacies and architectural elements.

Orientation of cross-strata and bounding surfaces were measured in order to evaluate

paleocurrents and the orientation of architectural elements relative to paleoflow directions.

The hierarchy of the bounding surfaces from the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation is presented on

tables 1 and 2. The interpretation of facies and architectural elements are summarized on

tables 3, 4 and 5. Statistical summary of paleocurrent is on Table (Tabela 16 dos Anexos).

RESULTS

Architectural Elements

AE1 – Unit Bars and Large Compound Dunes

This element is one of the most common in the studied exposures and comprises tabular

beds of pebbly coarse-grained sandstones with large-scale cross-bedding that frequently

transition to and from compound cross-sets (Fig. 11). Therefore, compound cross-sets

of this element are distinguishable from compound cross-sets of accretion in compound

bars (see below). Tabular beds composed by a single, 1 to 5 meters thick (averaging

1.5 m) cross-bed set, are the diagnostic characteristic of this element, showing internal

tabular or, less frequently, trough cross stratification. Convolute cross bedding is common,

at some places resulting in the obliteration of previous structures, but usually laterally

associated with single large cross-sets. Individual beds extend from 10 m to 50 m in the

dip direction. The upper bounding surface of the element is frequently of one of three types

(Tables 1 and 2): channel-base surfaces, bar increment surfaces or unit bar / compound

dune superimposition surfaces. Lower bounding surfaces of the element are either bar

increment surfaces or unit bar / compound dune superimposition surfaces. Paleocurrent

measurements carried out on this element show a mean vector per outcrop either towards

the southeast or the southwest (Table 6 - Anexos). Lateral variations of the single large

cross-sets are characterized by transitions to compound cross-strata sets, while maintaining

the total thickness and tabular geometry of the element. Compound cross-sets of this

element correspond to the vertical stacking of inclined cosets, generally dipping 10 to 15o

in the same direction as the related large-scale cross sets, but sometimes at high angles

or even in the opposite direction. The passage of individual large-scale beds to or from

compound cross-sets is usually characterized by a reactivation surface which dips less than

the previous cross strata and is parallel to the cross-set boundaries of the above compound

strata (Fig. 11). On the other hand, the passage from compound cross strata into a

single large scale set is given by a reactivation surface that dips more than the previous

set boundaries and is parallel to the above cross strata (Figs. 13 and 14). Thickness

of individual cross sets in the compound cross strata range from 5 cm to 1 m, with an

average of 20 cm. Elements of unit bars or large compound dunes often superpose each

other, giving rise to low angle climbing surfaces (superimposition surfaces, table 2) and

nucleating the element of downstream accretion compound bars (AE2 below).

Interpretation

This element is interpreted as the result of the migration of trains of semi-periodic unit

bars or periodic large dunes with straight crests, which transition to compound mesoforms

with dunes migrating on their lee-side face due to variation in the flow conditions. High

angle cross stratification is interpreted as the result of alternating of grain flow and grain

fall on the foresets combined with previous sorting by smaller bedforms migrating on the

stoss side of the large-scale mesoforms. High angle compound cross-sets may be the result

of migration of superimposed dunes with highs more than 25% of the host bedform (Reesink

Bridge 2007, 2009, 2011), but compound cross-sets with set-boundaries dipping less than

15o mark a change in the morphology of the host mesoforms, indicating the migration of

superimposed bedforms on the lee-side of the host bedform, possibly due to flow depth

variation.

The evidence of climb of similar elements indicate that these forms are periodic

or quasi-periodic, therefore being distinguishable from compound bars, even when the

thickness of each element is of up to 5 meters. The characterization of this element as the

deposits of large mesoforms imply in their amplitude being scaled to the depth of the flow

(e.g. Jackson, 1975 and Ashley, 1990).

AE2 - Downstream Accretion Compound Bar

The other most common element in the studied exposures is composed of coarse to

pebbly sandstones with compound cross stratification, characterized by low angle cross-set

boundaries and internal trough cross stratification. This element is distinguishable from

AE1 in not showing lateral transitions to single large-scale cross-set, in having lower

angle coset bounding surfaces, and in showing complex evolution, frequently with internal

surfaces of higher hierarchy (Figs. 12, 13, 14 and 15). Thickness of individual cross-sets

vary from 0.05 m to 1.0 m, while the whole element frequently compose tabular beds

several meters thick. Internal geometry of the element is of tabular or wedge shaped layers

that are gently inclined relative to its top and bottom boundaries. The main internal

surfaces are composed of set (small dune superimposition surfaces) and coset boundaries

(coset bounding surfaces), with local compound bar increment surfaces (Table 1). Soft

sediment deformation is frequent, with stratification planes showing convolute folding and

sets and cosets that appear disrupted and record flame and pillow structures ranging from

a few centimeters (0.05 m) to 2 m in thickness. This element commonly shows tabular



62

geometry, with an average extension of 50 m, locally reaching 500 m in width, and and

a maximum thicknesses of several meters. The element is commonly associated with bar

top (AE5), eolian dunes (AE4), and unit bar/large dune (AE1) elements. The upper

and lower bounding surfaces are bar top surfaces or major channel base surfaces (Table 2),

while the most frequent internal surfaces are unit bar / large dune superimposition surfaces

and compound bar increment surfaces. The latter frequently shows the preservation of a

pebble lag a few centimeters thick (2 – 10 cm), that is often inclined at low angles (¡ 5o).

The average attitudes of inclined set boundaries and compound bar increment surfaces are

similar to those of the cross beds, dipping to the south.

Interpretation

The element is interpreted as the deposits of compound bars formed by the vertical and

downstream stacking of dunes and unit bars, normally resulting in up to 0.5 m thick inclined

cross-sets arranged in several meters-thick bar increments. The presence of pebbles lags

associated with increment surfaces can be explained by selective transport of finer particles

during wanning flow. Relations between paleocurrents and bar increment surfaces point to

dominant downstream accretion, suggesting the dominance of braid bars. The dominance

of downstream inclined compound bar increment surfaces and set and coset bounding

surfaces indicates the preferential preservation of deposits from the bar tails.

AE3 – Minor Channel Fill

This element comprises the infill of tabular or gentle concave up erosional surfaces that

are 15 to 70 m wide and 1 to 4 m thick. The bottom surface frequently shows concave

up form, normally overlying bar top deposits (AE5) or eolian dunes (AE4). The upper

boundary of the element is often a simple plane surface overlain by downstream accretion

compound bar (AE2) or unit bar / large compound dune (AE1) elements (Fig. 16). The

internal organization of the element is frequently given by cosets of pebbly sandstones with

tabular cross stratification or trough cross stratification that vary from 10 cm up to 1m

in thickness. Sometimes mud intraclasts are present within pebbly sandstones that cut

siltstones lenses. Another type of fill, which occurs is given by structureless conglomerates

with imbricated pebbles (Fig. 17).

Interpretation

This channel fill element is interpreted as small-scale cross bar channels or chute

channels, distinguished from the major channels which are filled by AE1 and AE2. Spacial

relations of the minor channel fill element with bar top element (AE5) and with the aeolian

dune element (AE4) are the main evidence supporting this interpretation.

AE4 - Eolian Dunes

This element comprises 1 to 15 m thick sets of well sorted fine-grained cross bedded

sandstone, with lengths from 3 m to a few dozen meters. These are either laterally scoured

by channels filled by downstream accretion compound bars (AE2) and unit bars / large

compound dune deposits (AE1) or overlain by bar top deposits (AE5). In the former case

the main bounding surface at the top is a channel base surface which is irregular and can

reach 40 m in length, frequently covered by pebble lags and immediately overlain by pebbly

sandstones with tabular cross stratification (Fig. 18). Successions comprising several

cross-sets can reach 100 m in thickness. Paleocurrent analysis points to a north-northeast

direction of transport for this element. A large sand body dominated by this element is

exposed in an area of over 100 km2 in the northwest part of the Central Tucano sub-basin.

Interpretation

This element is interpreted as the product of the migration of eolian dunes on different

settings, ranging from isolated individual dunes in fluvial bar top settings to small dune

fields. The deposition of eolian dunes in a fluvial context strongly suggests the wind

reworking of sediments from sub-aerially exposed fluvial bars.

AE5 - Bar Top Deposits

This element is composed of channelized, tabular or lenticular sediment bodies that

vary from 10 to 100 m in length and from 0.2 to 1 m in thickness, in which laminated

siltstone and sandy siltstone with heterolythic lamination are the dominant lithologies,

with less frequent siltstone with root marks, and sandstone with sub and supercritical

cross-lamination and plane-parallel lamination (Fig. 12). The lower boundary surface of

the element is normally a gradual transition from AE1 or AE2 (Fig. 19).

Interpretation

The element is interpreted as shallow water traction deposits, associated with settling of

fines over bar tops, in areas where the downstream accretion compound bars were partially

or totally exposed, allowing for the development of small pounds (of up to tens of meters

of area). In this context, plane-bedded fine to medium-grained sandstone is interpreted

as the product of shallow rapid flow, whereas cross-laminated sandstone is interpreted

as the product of decelerating shallow flow in bar-top ponds or the upper part of bar

tails. The local presence of root-marks and the association of this element with eolian

reworking (element AE4) evidence subaerial exposition. The recognition of this element

is instrumental in the mapping of the superimposition of compound bar complexes of

distinct episodes of deposition since, according to Bristow (1996), the preservation of bar

top deposits is indicative of avulsion of the main channel.

Association Among Elements

The association of AE1 and AE2, composing stacked successions of interpreted unit bars

or large compound dunes deposits and downstream accretion compound bars characterizes

the greater part of the studied exposures (Fig. 19). The vertical transition from AE1

into AE2 suggests the nucleation of downstream bars by climbing large mesoforms (either

dunes or unit bars) in the deep parts of channels, in a similar way to that described by

Ashworth et al. (2000). On the other hand, the association of AE1 with bar top deposits

(AE5) indicates the presence of unit bars also in bar head environments (e.g. Bridge, 2003),

suggesting that the frequent intercalation of the elements AE1 and AE2 may be related

to the preservation of bar head and bar tail deposits. Less frequent is the occurrence of

associations related to bar tops (AE5), bar top channels (AE3) and eolian reworking (AE4),

which intercalate bar deposits and define major boundaries possibly related to channel belt

avulsion.

DISCUSSION

The recognition of two different types of compound cross-strata, one related to

interpreted downstream accretion compound bars (AE2) and the other related to unit

bars or large compound dunes (AE1) presents a difficulty to the application of hierarchical

classifications of bounding surfaces, as proposed by Miall (e.g. 1996). The surface of

superimposition of unit bars or large dunes can be preserved as simple set boundaries,

but the lateral change of large scale foresets into compound cross strata implies in the

same surface being a simple set boundary and laterally turning into a surface bounding

compound cross strata (Fig. 13). In this case, reactivation and changes in grain-size and

orientation of sedimentary structures due to changes in water discharge can be mistaken

for increments in a macroform (Figs. 11 and 12). Thus, unit bars and large dunes may

evolve into compound dunes and record flood events in a similar way to compound bars,

despite being scaled to the water depth and therefore much smaller than the compound

bars of the same system. In this way, the hierarchical classification of surfaces in large river

deposits shows a higher degree of complexity, and an alternative designation of surfaces

by terms reflecting their interpreted origin is preferable (Tables 1 and 1), following the

approach adopted for eolian deposits (e.g. Mountney 2006). It must be noted that the

attribution of time-scales for architectural elements as proposed by Miall (e.g. 1996) is also

misleading in the case of large rivers, since it has been demonstrated that kilometer-scale

bars (e.g. Ashworth et al., 2000) can be formed in the time span originally attributed to

meter-scale increments (seazonal to few years cycles of major floods).

In large rivers, some mesoforms (large dunes and unit bars) can be of similar scale to

the macroforms (compound bars) of smaller rivers, which are the basis for the current facies

models. As the large size of the bedforms that are scaled with the flow depth (mesoforms)

is one of the best evidence for the recognition of big river deposits (e.g. Miall, 2006,

Fielding, 2007), the distinction between large mesoforms of big rivers and macroforms

of smaller rivers is critical. In this way, Miall and Jones (2003) distinguished deposits

of downstream bars from an element of compound dunes in the Hawkesbury Sandstone

succession (southeastern Australia), interpreted to be the depositional product of a big

river system.

In the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation, meter-scale compound cross-bedding, interpreted

as unit bar or large compound dune deposits, are the main element to interpret the

dominance of several meters deep channels. These are distinguished from the interpreted

downstream accretion compound bar deposits because they laterally pass into large-scale

(up to five meters thick) avalanche foreset, which on their turn are bounded by low angle

superposition (climbing) surfaces of similar elements, thus attesting their origin in periodic

or semi-periodic bedforms. The latter characteristic is central in setting unit bars and large

dunes apart from compound bars, as avalanche foresets can be found in bar deposits (e.g.

Best et al. 2003), but bars do not systematically climb each other as do dunes of the same

train or semi-periodic unit bars.

CONCLUSIONS

The detailed study of large-scale exposures of the Early Cretaceous Sa?o Sebastia?o

Formation of Northeastern Brazil, composed mainly of cross-stratified pebbly coarse

sandstones, lead to the characterization of five main fluvial architectural elements: unit

bars and large compound dunes, downstream accretion compound bars, minor channel

fills, eolian dunes and bar top deposits, related to bounding surfaces classified according

to their interpreted origin.

The distinction between the downstream bar element and the unit bar and large

compound dune element was based on the recognition of lateral transitions of large-scale

(up to five meters) avalanche foresets into compound cross-sets coupled with the recognition

of low angle superposition (climbing) surfaces between unit bars and/or large dunes.

The abundance of the latter element is considered as evidence for deep channels, thus

characterizing a large river system. The identification of the element of unit bar and large

compound dunes, and its distinction from downstream accretion compound bar deposits,

may though be useful in the identification and documentation of the architecture of large

river deposits.

6.2. Artigo 2 – Fluvial Bars and Floodplain deposits near a

high accommodation zone (Neocomian to Barremian Sa?o

Sebastia?o Formation, Tucano Basin, Northeastern Brazil)

- a ser submetido a? revista Brazilian Journal of Geology.

Abstract

Rift basins are characterized by great structural complexity, with the interaction

among transfer zones, master faults and minor faults controlling the structural highs and

depocenters. The distribution of these features results in differential rates of subsidence and

accommodation, implying in variations in the form of preservation and in the architecture

of fluvial systems. Areas with higher rates of accommodation can be responsible for

greater preservation of architectural elements related to floodplains. Scenarios of this

type are found in the eastern part of the Tucano Central Sub-Basin, where occurred the

highest rate of accommodation in the whole Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? rift system (Early

Cretaceous, Northeastern Brazil), related to the movement of a basin-border fault near the

C??cero Dantas low and the Vaza Barris Transfer Zone. In this area, fluvial deposits of the

Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation crop out (Neocomina to Barremian), showing the intercalation

between the deposits of sandy fluvial bars and fine-grained floodplains. The interaction

between these elements is interpreted as the consequence of frequent channel avulsion, on

its turn induced by local tectonic movements capable of shifting the channels laterally

and thus promoting abandonment and the installation of environments dominated by the

settling of fine particles. The comparison of these deposits with the successions dominated

by sandy bars of the central areas of the same basin suggest that local tectonic controls,

variations in the tilt of the basin floor and higher subsidence rates were responsible for the

preservation of the floodplain deposits.



84

Resumo

Bacias tipo rift sa?o marcadas por grande complexidade estrutural, caracterizada pela

interac?a?o entre zonas de transfere?ncia, falhas mestras e falhas menores controlando altos

estruturais e depocentros. A distribuic?a?o destas feic?o?es resulta em taxas de subside?ncia

e de gerac?a?o de espac?o de acomodac?a?o diferenciados, implicando em variac?o?es na forma

de preservac?a?o e na arquitetura de sistemas fluviais. A?reas com taxas de acomodac?a?o

mais elevadas podem ser responsa?veis pela maior preservac?a?o de elementos arquiteturais

relacionados a plan??cies de inundac?a?o. Cena?rios deste tipo ocorrem na borda leste da

sub-bacia Tucano Central, onde ocorreu a mais elevada taxa de acomodac?a?o do sistema

de rifte do Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? (Eocreta?ceo, Nordeste do Brasil), relacionada a?

movimentac?a?o da falha de borda, pro?ximo ao Baixo de C??cero Dantas e a? zona de

transfere?ncia do Vaza Barris. Nesta a?rea ocorrem depo?sitos fluviais da Formac?a?o Sa?o

Sebastia?o (Neocomiano a Barremiano) com intercalac?o?es entre depo?sitos de barras arenosas

e de plan??cies de inundac?a?o. A interac?a?o entre esses elementos foi interpretada como

produto de frequente avulsa?o, por sua vez, induzida por movimentac?o?es tecto?nicas locais,

capazes de deslocar o canal principal lateralmente, promovendo seu abandono e posterior

instalac?a?o de ambiente dominado por depo?sitos de decantac?a?o. A comparac?a?o desses

depo?sitos com sucesso?es dominadas pela superposic?a?o de barras arenosas no centro da bacia

sugere que fatores tecto?nicos, variac?o?es na inclinac?a?o do substrato e as taxas de subside?ncia

mais elevadas exerceram controles locais na preservac?a?o de plan??cies de inundac?a?o.

Keywords

Fluvial bars, floodplains, avulsion, Tucano Basin, Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation

Palavras-chave

Barras fluviais, plan??cies de inundac?a?o, avulsa?o, Bacia Tucano, Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o



85

INTRODUCTION

The complexity of the structural framework of rift basins, characterized by the

interplay between faults with varied attitude and displacement and the development of

internal highs, depocenters and transfer zones (e.g. Rosendahl 1987, Morley et al. 1990,

Rosendahl et al. 1992), leads to a complex spatial distribution of subsidence rates (e.g.

Gawthorpe et al. 1994). This spatial variation of subsidence can cast influences in the

architecture of fluvial systems, creating coeval settings of high- and low- accommodation

in the same basin (e.g. Leckie and Boyd, 2003), characterized, among other features, by

variations in the sedimentation rates, preservation of floodplain deposits, frequency and

connectivity of channel sand-bodies, and frequency and development of paleosols. Fluvial

systems with high proportions of preserved floodplain deposits are commonly associated

with the high sinuosity of channels, reduced slope gradients and small rates of lateral

migration of the channel belt (e.g. Miall, 1996, Bridge 2006). Therefore, a change from

a bed-load dominated braided fluvial system in the low-accommodation setting in the

basin to a mixed-load meandering system in the high-accommodation setting could be

expected. Nevertheless, the characterization of the accommodation controls on fluvial

channel style are not well documented. The Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation (Early Cretaceous,

Northeastern Brazil) comprises thick (up to 3000 m) fluvial successions, composed mostly

of pebbly sandstones previously interpreted as braided river deposits (Figueiredo et al.

2013, submitted). The unit was deposited in a rift basin (Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba?

rift) during the extensional events that culminated in the opening of the South Atlantic

Ocean. This formation crops out in different structural domains in the basin, including

an area above its deepest depocenter, the C??cero Dantas low, and another inside the Vaza

Barris Transfer Zone, both located in the Central Tucano sub-basin (Fig. 1), enabling

the characterization of the fluvial architecture and interpreted channel styles in a clearly

characterized high-accommodation setting.

GEOLOGICAL SETTING

The Central Tucano sub-basin is the best exposed portion, in Eastern Brazil, of an

aborted rift system which culminated with the opening of the South Atlantic ocean. It

is a 100 km long and 60 km wide sub-basin mainly controlled by N-S master fault at the

eastern border and secondarily by transversal structures. Subsurface data show an area of

intense lithospheric stretching which governed the onset of mechanical subsidence (Ussami



86

Figura 20. Geological map of the Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? (RTJ) Rift and its adjacent basement rocks,
highlighting the outcrops of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation. Figure modified from Gava et al. 1983,
Magnavita et al. 2003, Barbosa and Sabate? 2004.



87

et al. 1986, Milani and Davison, 1988).

This portion of the basin is also affected by the Vaza Barris Transfer Zone, which

actuated as an accommodation area that transferred the movement of the eastern master

border fault to another fault located on the opposite side at the Northern Tucano sub-basin

(Magnavita, 1996) (Fig. 1). The main border fault of the Central Tucano sub-basin

controlled its depocenter, located in the region of C??cero Dantas, where the deepest lows

reach 10,000 m depth (Magnavita et al., 2003), filled by lacustrine, fluvial and alluvial-fan

deposits.

The maximum thickness of the Neocomian and Barremian (140 -125 Ma) Sa?o Sebastia?o

Formation is of 3050 m near the study area (Magnavita et al., 2003). Previous

interpretation of outcrops and core logs (e.g. Viana et al., 1971, Sensora, 1982) lead

to the proposition of a fluvial origin for most of these sandstones, indicating a prolonged

period of fluvial deposition during intense tectonic activity of the border fault. Previous

paleocurrent analysis point to a southward mean direction of transport the whole unit

(Sensora, 1982).

Works based on seismic profiles defined the basin-scale reflectors and indicate, from

their geometric patterns, that the uppermost record of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation is

exposed on the eastern part of the Central Tucano sub-basin, and also that it resembles

the arrangement of braided river channel belts that prograded towards the south (e.g.

Magnavita et al.. 2003; Costa et al., 2007a,b).

METHODS

The analysis of the architecture of fluvial deposits from the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formaton was

made in six outcrops located in the eastern border of the Central Tucano sub-basin, along

the BR-110. Rock exposures of up to 10 m height and few hundred meters long were subject

of facies and architectural element analysis (e.g. Reading, 1986, Walker, 1992, Miall,

1990, Miall, 1996 and Miall, 2000). Columnar stratigraphic sections and outcrop maps

based on photomosaics were elaborated to represent the vertical and lateral distribution of

lithofacies and architectural elements. Orientation of cross-strata and bounding surfaces

were measured in order to evaluate paleocurrents and the orientation of architectural

elements relative to paleoflow directions. The hierarchy of the bounding surfaces from

the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation is presented on Tables 6, 7. The interpretation of lithofacies

and architectural elements are summarized on Tables 3, 4, 5.



88

RESULTS

Facies Analysis and Architectural Elements

The combination of facies and architectural element analyses led to the identification

of fifteen facies (Tables 6, 7), eight bounding surfaces (Tables 8, 9) and seven architectural

elements (Unit Bars and large compound dunes – AE1, Downstream Accretion Compound

Bar - AE2, Minor Channel Fill – AE3, Eolian Dunes – AE4, Floodplain Fines - AE5,

Abandoned Channel - AE6, Crevasse Splay – AE7) (Table 10).

UNIT BARS AND LARGE COMPOUND DUNES– AE1

This element is one of the most common in the studied exposures and comprises

tabular beds of pebbly coarse-grained sandstones with large-scale cross-bedding (Fig. 21).

The beds are composed by a single, more than 1 m thick (averaging 1.5 m) cross-bed

set, which is the diagnostic characteristic of this element, showing internal tabular or,

less frequently, trough cross stratification. Notice that the compound cross-sets of this

element are distinguishable from compound cross-sets of accretion in compound bars (see

below). Convolute cross bedding is common, at some places resulting in the obliteration

of previous structures, but usually laterally associated with single large cross-sets (Fig.

22 A). Individual beds extend from 10 m to 30 m towards dip direction and frequently

have internal surfaces steeper than the surface bounding the host bedform, resulting in

the record of a bedform reactivation surface – 2 (Table 8). The upper bounding surface

of the element is frequently of one of these three types (Tables 8 and 9): channel-base

surfaces, bar increment surfaces or unit bar / compound dune superimposition surfaces.

Lower bounding surfaces of the element are either bar increment surfaces or unit bar /

compound dune superimposition surfaces. Paleocurrent data from this element show a

mean vector per outcrop either towards the southeast or the southwest.

INTERPRETATION

This element is interpreted as the result of the migration of trains of semi-periodic unit

bars or periodic large dunes with straight crests, which transition to compound mesoforms

with smaller dunes migrating on their lee-side face due to variation in the flow conditions.

High-angle cross-stratification is interpreted as the result of alternating grain flow and

grain fall on the foresets, combined with previous sorting by smaller bedforms migrating



89

Tabela 6. Summary of the lithofacies of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation



90

Tabela 7. Summary of the lithofacies of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation



91

on the stoss side of the large-scale mesoforms. High-angle compound cross-sets may be the

result of migration of superimposed dunes with heights more than 25% of the host bedform

(Reesink Bridge 2007, 2009, 2011), but compound cross-sets with boundaries dipping less

than 15o mark a change in the morphology of the host mesoforms, indicating the migration

of superimposed bedforms on the lee-side of the host bedform, possibly due to flow depth

variation.

DOWNSTREAM ACCRETION COMPOUND BAR - AE2

Downstream accretion compound bars are chiefly individual sandstone beds with

tabular or gently dipping geometry with individual set thickness ranging from 0.05 m to 1 m

(Figs. 21, 22 C and 23). The vertical stacking of sets comprises few meters thick successions

(4 m), frequently with 100 m of lateral extension, which are bounded at the bottom by

channel-base surfaces – 6 (Figs. 21 and 23). Internally, the sets are composed of sandstones

with tabular and trough cross-stratification (Fig. 22 B), or compound cross-stratification

with cosets of 0.10 to 1 m thick, generally with inclined set boundaries in the opposite

direction of climbing (small dune superimposition surfaces - 1). These structures are locally

convoluted, sometimes with complete obliteration of the stratification. The main internal

surfaces are inclined set (small dune superimposition surfaces - 1) and coset bounding

surfaces - 3, as well as bar increment surfaces (4) showing average dips towards the south

(Tables 8 and 9), the latter frequently dipping more than the foreset and in the same

direction of the paleoflow.

INTERPRETATION

This element is interpreted as the result of migrating braid bars, with dominant

downstream accretion.

MINOR CHANNEL FILL - AE3

This element comprises the fill of gently concave up structures scouring the upper

bounding of unit bars (AE1) and downstream accretion bars (AE2). The bottom of the

element is limited by a channel-base surface – 6 (Tables 8 and 9) that ranges from 3 to

80 m length and has the flat top surface bounded by an bar increment surface – 4, which

separates it from the overlain AE2. The main fill is composed of fine sandstone with

plane-parallel lamination (F1) and medium to coarse-grained sandstone with tabular or

INTERPRETATION

This channel fill element is interpreted as small-scale cross bar channels or chute

channels, distinguished from the major or abandoned channels (AE6).

EOLIAN DUNES – AE4

This element is composed of very fine to fine-grained cross-bedded and well sorted

sandstone organized in thin strata that varies from 1 to 2 m thick and can reach maximum

lateral extent of 15 m (Fig. 22G,H). This element is either deposited as tabular or gently

trough sets at the top of the Unit bars (AE1) or Floodplain fines (AE5), in which they

are bounded at the bottom by eolian reworking surface – 7, which erodes the underlying

strata, recording an irregular and inclined surface frequently in the opposed direction of

migrating bedforms (Figs. 23 and 24). Another, but less frequent, geometry associated

with the element is a wedge-shaped body that varies from 1 to 3 m thick, which is bounded

on top by a channel-base surface - 6 and and at the bottom by an eolian surface, which

separates it from underlying and overlying downstream accretion bar elements (AE2) (Fig.

25). Paleocurrent data reveal a mean vector to the southwest.

INTERPRETATION

This element is interpreted as the result of the migration of eolian dunes due to wind

reworking at the overbank environments or at the top of stabilized downstream accretion

bars (AE2). The interpretation of paleocurrent suggest two paleowind directions, one to

southeast and another to southwest.

FLOODPLAIN FINES - AE5

This element is composed of tabular or lenticular bodies that vary from 10 to more

than 100 m length and from 0.2 cm to 3.5 m thick (Figs. 21, 23, 24). The predominant

fill is composed of thin laminated siltstone with convolute laminae, sandy siltstone with

heterolythic lamination, frequently overlain by mudstones and scarce mudstones with root

marks (Fig. 27 A, B, C). These facies are occasionally interbedded with tabular sets

of fine- and medium-grained sandstone with current and wave ripples or plane-parallel

100

lamination, which form sets with an average thickness of 0.5 m. The floodplain deposits are

frequently related to high ranking bounding surfaces, such as channel-base and floodplain

basal surfaces. Most of the floodplain deposits described were apparently sub-horizontal or

gently inclined northwards and affected by normal or inverse faults with few centimeters

displacements (Figs. 23, 24). The filling of the architectural element is often lain over an

horizontal bed, but the dip angle in lower bounding surfaces, although gentle, indicates

local erosion before the onlaping deposits of fine-grained facies.

INTERPRETATION

This element is interpreted as the product of settling of fine-grained particles during

decelerating flow or stagnant water after major floods. The interbedding of tabular sets

of sandstone are the distal product of the lower reaches of crevasse splays, which were

responsible by the sand input in the flood basin area, rendering an environment similar to

the models proposed by Bown Kraus (1987) and Fielding (1986).

ABANDONED CHANNEL - AE6

This element is formed by a concave up structure 70 m wide and 12 m thick succession

(Fig. 26), mainly composed of sandy siltstones with plane-parallel lamination and fine and

very fine sandstones with climbing ripples (Fig. 27 – E), with less frequency of small-scale

tabular cross stratification in the form of lenses (3 to 5 m long and 0.1 to 0.2 m thick), .

The top of the element contains ripple marks with straight crest lines overlying a 1.5 m

thick succession of siltstones (Fig. 27 - F). The lower bounding surface is a channel-base

surface (7), which separates it from underlaying accretion bar element (AE2).

INTERPRETATION

This element was interpreted as the settling of silt, clay and sand from suspension inside

a small lake in the overbank area similar with the deposition on lacustrine environments

(Miall,1996), which in turn were formed either by lateral shifting of the main channel, or

by the abandonment of crevasse channels and small draining channels inside the floodplain

(Bridge, 2003). The recognition of ripple marks with straight crest lines can be the result

of wave action, which points to a possible deposition in a lake environment, but is not

exclusive of this environment in overbank areas (Bridge, 2003).

Figura 27. Facies fromFloodplain Fines (A – Heterolythic lamination, B – Sandy siltstones with convolute

103

CREVASSE SPLAY - AE7

The element geometry is a sandstone body that dips southwards in a moderate angle

and is bounded by a floodplain-basal surface – S8 (Table 9). It is mainly composed of up

to 0.5 m thick sets of tabular and trough cross stratification (Fig. 27 – G, H), and less

frequent plane-parallel lamination, totalizing a 1.80 m thick wedge (Fig. 28). It represents

a lateral extension of 10 m, underlies and is overlain by the floodplain element(AE5).

Laterally northwards it becomes concave up above the downstream accretion compound

bar (AE2), which clearly resembles a local positive relief (extreme right of Fig. 28). The

paleocurrent of this element was obtained from the measurement of trough and tabular

cross stratification. They revealed a mean vector to the south.

INTERPRETATION

This element is interpreted as the deposits of a levee that advanced into the overbank

environment. Although the lateral extension is by far smaller than those interpreted

by Miall, 1996, which points to an order of thousands of meters, the wedge shape is

characteristic of levees in modern rivers (Bridge 2003, Smith Perez-Arlucea 1994) and the

top of the element resembles minor channel fills, which can be interpreted as the transition

of the channel into levee element (Miall, 1996; Bristow et al.1999). The paleocurrent

indicates that the migration of bedforms during the crevasse splay was southwards.

Spatial relation among elements

The most common architecture found on the studied exposures is characterized by the

alternation of channel macroforms (Unit bars – AE1 and Downstream accretion compound

bars - AE2) and the deposits of overbank environments, dominated by settling processes

(Floodplain fines - AE5, abandoned channel - AE6 and crevasse splays - AE7). The latter

interpreted elements are similar to the overbank environments described from modern and

ancient deposits (e.g. Nanson Crooke, 1992, Miall 1996, Bridge 2008). Eolian beds (AE4)

are found in association with the overbank successions, and record local eolian reworking

of exposed surfaces.

Local minor-channel fills (AE3) are composed of well-sorted fine sandstone with

plane-beds and small-scale bedforms, indicating high froude numbers and thus small water

depths and faster current flow during their deposition. The abrupt passage of channel-base



104

Tabela 10. Descrition and interpretation of architectural elements of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation near
the C??cero Dantas low



105

surfaces at the bottom of the element can be related to the development of shallow bar-top

channels (Bridge, 2006) that could partly erode the bar-top of the bar succession, which

is corroborated by the spatial relation with channel bars (Fig. 21 – Part 1, Fig. 29 – Part

1).

DISCUSSION

The integration of facies, paleocurrent and architectural element analysis allowed to

interpret the exposures of the upper part of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation in the eastern

Tucano Central sub-basin as a mixed-load fluvial system dominated by downstream

accretion bars and with the preservation of overbank deposits, frequently associated with

the avulsion of small fluvial channels. The frequent occurrence of convolute beds probably

indicates seismic activity, which is in accordance with the interpreted syn-rift setting for

the succession.

Considering that the studied area exposes a greater proportion of floodplain and

fine-grained bar top deposits than the remaining areas of the Tucano Central sub-basin

(Figueiredo et al. 2013 submitted), and that this particular area is partly coincident

with the depocenter of the sub-basin (C??cero Dantas low – see Fig.20), controlled by the

master basin border fault to the east, a model integrating the fluvial architecture and

the syn-depositional tectonic model (e.g. Magnavita, 1996) can be proposed. Two main

controls of the local tectonic setting on the fluvial architecture must be considered: (1)

the greater rates of accommodation space generation in the area of maximum subsidence,

which can account for the enhanced preservation of overbank deposits, and (2) a tendency

to frequent channel avulsion in response to both the higher rates of alluvial plain accretion

and the tectonic tilting of the basin floor towards the basin border fault. In this way the

tectonic control on the river system could either shift the channels laterally (e.g. Alexander

et al. 1994; Peakall et al. 2000) or increase the subsidence rate (Miall, 1996), thus

contributing to more frequent avulsions into subsiding floodplains (Bridge, 2006). This

seems to be the case when we compare the number and frequency of avulsion surfaces

in the area of the present study with that of the basin center (Figueiredo et al. 2013

submitted).

The greater subsidence rates, which are the highest in the whole Tucano-Reco?ncavo-Jatoba?

rift system, conditioned by the existence of a master fault (Magnavita et al 2003), also

favor the preservation of floodplains (Bentham et al. 1993) and can explain the onlap

pattern described in several of the outcrops (Figs. 4, 5, 11), which could be the result

109

of a lateral migration of the channel belt. The high rates of accommodation generation

can also account for the greater preservation of the shallow parts of fluvial bars, including

bar-top pounds, deposits of eolian reworking and small bar-top channels (Bridge, 2008).

Regarding the channel style of the studied successions, the dominance of downstream

accretion bars suggest low sinuosity braided channels (e.g. Miall, 1996), but nevertheless

there is evidence for local variability in the channel style. The recognized wedge shaped

crevasse splay element (AE7) dips parallel to the main flow of the accretion bars (AE2)

suggesting that, locally, some channels in this area of the basin could have had high

sinuosity. This may suggest episodic reduction in the slope gradient, since tectonic

subsidence can promote morphological variations in fluvial styles (Alexander Leeder, 1987;

Bridge, 1993b) which can, on their turn, promote changes in fluvial channel morphology.

An alternative interpretation is the existence of smaller high sinuosity channels cutting

trough the overbank areas and coexisting with the main braided fluvial system, as pointed

by Bridge (2003).

The marked differences between the architecture of the Sa?o Sebastia?o formation on

the exposures in the area of the C??cero Dantas depocenter and the successions of other

areas of the Central Tucano sub-basin (Figueiredo et al. 2013 submitted) indicate that the

local tectonic controls on slope gradient, accommodation generation and basin floor tilting

probably prevailed over the regional sedimentary input and drainage basin characteristics

in constructing a particular fluvial environment in the studied area of the basin.

CONCLUSIONS

The architectural element analyses from the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation allowed the

interpretation of seven elements in the eastern border of the Central Tucano sub-basin:

AE1 – Unit bars and Large compound dunes, AE2 – Downstream accretion compound

bar, AE3 – Minor Channel Fills, AE4 – Eolian Dunes, AE5 – Floodplain fines, AE6 –

Abandoned Channels, AE7 – Crevasse Splay. The interplay of these elements suggests the

presence of a mixed load fluvial setting, dominated by the alternation of sandy fluvial bars

that migrated southwards and the deposition of overbank environments in areas of higher

gradient slope, inherited after local erosion and abandonment of growth of channel-bars.

In order to explain the spatial relation of bars and overbank environments at the eastern

border where subsidence rates are highest, we proposed two major tectonic controls: (1)

the highest accommodation space rates may have contributed to the preservation of the

overbank environments that could not be eroded; (2) processes of channel avulsion in a



110

high frequency could be the response either to the high accretion rates at the floodplain as

due to the tectonic tilt of the basin floor towards the eastern master fault. Such controls

indicate that local tectonics probably prevailed over the regional sedimentary input and

drainage basin in the studied area.
