6.3. Artigo 3 - Abrupt change in maturity in a rift basin as a

consequence of activation of the basin-border faults: the

Sa?o Sebastia?o and Marizal formations (early cretaceous)

in the Tucano Basin (Northeastern Brazil)

– submetido a? revista Basin Research

ABSTRACT

Abrupt changes in maturity of sandstone and conglomerate in tectonically active basins

can be considered either as the product of rapid climatic change or of tectonic restructuring

of the feeder drainage system. Besides these regional controls, changes in the configuration

of local sources can expressively affect the composition of the basin fill. The Early

Cretaceous fluvial successions of the Tucano Basin, a rift basin in Northeastern Brazil

related to the opening of the South Atlantic, contain one such case of abrupt change

in maturity, marked by the passage from pebbly sandstone and conglomerate rich in

quartz and quartzite fragments (neocomian to barremian Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation) to

more feldspathic pebbly sandstone and conglomerate bearing pebbles of varied composition

(aptian Marizal Formation). Systematic analysis of the stratigraphic and spatial variation

of paleocurrents and the composition of pebbles and cobbles from both units, integrated

with the recognition of the distribution of fluvial and alluvial fan deposits, lead to two

major conclusions: (1) Despite being regionally correlated to post-rift successions with

marine influence, the Marizal Formation is laterally equivalent to alluvial fan deposits fed

from an active fault scarp at the eastern border of the Tucano Basin. (2) The abrupt

increase in maturity during the passage from the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation to the Marizal

Formation can be explained by the activation of the basin border faults after the erosional

retreat of the original fault scarp. This process would have caused a reduction in the

local catchment areas and a consequent interruption of the contribution from paleozoic

successions rich in quartz and quartzite pebbles, which would be thereafter part of the

catchment of the drainage system flowing away from the basin. The same process would

expose the crystalline basement at the basin margins, thus causing the observed increase in

maturity. The proposed model has important implications for the interpretation of abrupt

changes in maturity in rift basin successions, since similar results are expected where

activation of basin border faults occurs after the erosional retreat of scarps developed in

older sedimentary or volcanic units.



114

1. INTRODUCTION

The distribution and composition of coarse-grained sediment in tectonically active

basins are controlled by the tectonic evolution of source-areas, the configuration of the

drainage systems, the patterns of weathering and exhumation of source rocks and the

evolution and spatial distribution of subsidence within the basin. Major shifts in the

composition of pebbles and cobbles in a sedimentary basin may result to changes in one or

more of these controls, and abrupt changes in maturity of sandstone and conglomerate in

tectonically active basins can be considered either as the product of rapid climatic change

or of tectonic restructuring of the feeder drainage system. Besides these regional controls,

changes in the configuration of local sources can expressively affect the composition of the

basin fill. The Early Cretaceous fluvial successions of the Tucano Basin (Northeastern

Brazil) contain one such case of abrupt change in maturity, marked by the passage from

pebbly sandstone and conglomerate rich in quartz and quartzite fragments (Sa?o Sebastia?o

Formation) to more feldspathic pebbly sandstone and conglomerate bearing pebbles of

varied composition (Marizal Formation). Both units are exposed in an area bounded

by normal faults, but whereas the Neocomian to Barremian Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation is

regionally correlated to continental syn-rift successions from the extensional events that

lead to the opening of the South Atlantic, the Aptian Marizal Formation is correlated

with post-rift successions with marine influence. This regional context lead to previous

interpretations of a thermal subsidence phase for the Marizal Formation (Magnavita, 1992;

Magnavita et al., 1994), implying in a model in which a more mature basin fill is deposited

during the phase of active tectonic subsidence than that of the subsequent phase of tectonic

quiescence.

In order to investigate the possible controls on the change in clast composition in the

Tucano Basin, systematic analyses of paleocurrents and pebble and cobble composition

in both units were performed, including the recognition of their stratigraphic and

spatial variability, leading to a model of predictable evolution of source areas that can

potentially be applied in other rift basins. Additionally, a new model is proposed for the

tectonic evolution of the Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? rift, with major implications for the

geological evolution of Eastern South America during the period of deposition of important

hydrocarbon reservoir successions further south (Campos and Santos Basins).



115

Figura 31. Geological map of the Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? (RTJ) Rift and its adjacent basement rocks,
highlighting the sampled outcrops of the Sa?o Sebastia?o and Marizal formations. Figure modified from
Magnavita (1996), Barbosa and Sabate? (2004) and Gava et al. (1983).



116

2. GEOLOGICAL FRAMEWORK

The Tucano Basin, in Northeastern Brazil, is part of the Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? Rift

(RTJ), a north-south trending sedimentary basin with more than 42,000 km2 of exposed

area, which is an aborted branch of the rift system formed during the opening of the South

Atlantic, in the Early Cretaceous. The Tucano Basin is subdivided in three sub-basins -

Northern, Central and Southern (Fig. 6.3) – by the Vaza Barris and Itapicuru structural

highs, recognized as transfer zones (Milani Davison, 1988). There is an inversion of

depocenter between the northern and central Tucano sub-basins, in response to the change

of the master fault from the west to the east.

The up to 4 km thick Neocomian to Barremian succession is interpreted as syn-rift

deposits, comprising alluvial-fan (Salvador Formation), lacustrine (Candeias Formation),

deltaic (Ilhas Group) and fluvial deposits (Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation), while up to 250 m

thick fluvial deposits of Aptian age (Marizal Formation) were deposited on an unconformity

and are considered as of post-rift setting (Magnavita, 1992; Magnavita et al., 1994; Costa

et al., 2007a; b).

The Sa?o Sebastia?o and Marizal formations are the best exposed units that crop out

along the RTJ. The alluvial-dominated units are mainly composed of sandstone and

conglomerate, with a minor contribution of siltstone and limestone, interpreted as fluvial,

alluvial fan and lacustrine deposits (e.g. Magnavita Cupertino, 1988; Milani Davison,

1988; Costa et al., 2007 a; b). The alluvial fan-dominated successions (Salvador Formation)

are restricted to the basin borders and are recognized in subsurface with a thickness of up

to 8,000 m.

In the Tucano Basin, the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation has a maximum thickness in

excess of 3,000 m, comprising pebbly sandstone of fluvial origin, with minor mudstone

and heterolithic strata. Most of the succession is composed of deposits of large scale

fluvial bars, forming several meters thick tabular sand bodies with internal compound

cross stratification, defined by inclined cosets of cross-bedded sandstones, with abundant

convolute strata (Fig. 6.3). These are locally overlain by associations of fine grained

sandstone with cross stratification, laminated siltstone, and heterolithic strata with root

marks, interpreted as bar tops and minor abandoned channels. Local eolian dune field

deposits are characterized by up to 15 m thick cross-sets of fine to medium sandstone.

The overlying Marizal Formation has an average preserved thickness of 250 m and rests

on a major unconformity over the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation. The unit is similar to the

Sa?o Sebastia?o formation, being composed of medium to coarse grained sandstone, often



117

Figura 32. General view of accretion bars of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation at the Central Tucano Basin.

conglomeratic, with planar and trough cross bedding, frequently disposed as meter-scale

compound cross-stratification in beds of tabular geometry. Coarser grained facies are

frequent, characterized as polymictic conglomerate and conglomeratic sandstone with

imbricated clasts and trough cross-stratification and plane beds (Fig. 6.3).

Figura 33. General view of a small outcrop of the Marizal Formation at the eastern border of the Central
Tucano Basin

Local coarse-grained deposits close to the eastern border of the Central Tucano

basin, with no clear stratigraphic relation with either of the above units, show inclined

amalgamated lenses of conglomerate. These deposits display clast imbrication, massive,

and crude stratification, the latter marked by grain-size variation, incipient grading, and

local interbedding of massive sandstone and trough cross-bedded conglomerate. These

deposits are interpreted as alluvial fan deposits (Fig. 6.3).

Age constraints for most of the Brazilian cretaceous sedimentary units are based

in biostratigraphic, isotopic, radiometric, and apatite fission-track age correlations (e.g.

Bueno, 2004; Milani et al., 2007). According to these authors, the bulk of the Sa?o Sebastia?o

Formation was deposited between 135 Ma and 124 Ma. Subsurface data show that, from

140 Ma to 135 Ma, this unit was laterally equivalent to the deltaic deposits of the Ilhas

Group in the Tucano and Jatoba? basins. Southward progradation of the fluvial deposits



118

Figura 34. Outcrops from the alluvial fans at the eastern margin of the basin (A) General view of the
conglomerate; (B) Detail of clast imbrication with a GPS device as scale; (C) Stratified sandstones with
conglomerate on top left.

of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation reached the Reco?ncavo Basin at approximately 130 Ma,

overlying thick deltaic and deep lacustrine successions. After a gap of approximately 8 Ma,

at approximately 116 Ma, the Marizal Formation was deposited on an erosional (locally

angular) unconformity. The preserved thickness of the Marizal Formation varies from a

maximum of 500 m in the Jatoba? Basin (e.g. Magnavita et al., 2003; Silva et al., 2007),

trough up to 300 m in the Tucano Basin, and into less than 100 m in the Reco?ncavo Basin.

Previous paleocurrent analysis also point to southward flow for the Marizal formation

(Lima Vilas Boas, 2000; Rolim Mabesoone,1982; Assine 1994; Santos et al. 2010). Yet,

there are no available provenance data for the Marizal and the Sa?o Sebastia?o formations,

except for the work of Gontijo (1988), which interpreted probable source areas to the north

and east, based on data from thin sections of sandstones.

The basement rocks surrounding the RTJ (Fig. 6.3) are divided into the following

units: (1) the Archean Serrinha Block, which is part of the Sa?o Francisco Craton and

is mainly composed of biotite gneiss, migmatite, charnockite, anphybolite, granitoid

intrusions (Barbosa Sabate?, 2004) and minor phyllite, metabasic dykes, chert and banded

iron formation; (2) the Neoproterozoic Sergipana Belt, which is part of the Borborema

Province and comprises metamorphic and granitoid rocks, chiefly composed of schist,



119

quartzite, phyllite, metasiltstone, metasandstone, leucocratic and biotite granite, rhyollite,

and a minor contribution of basic dykes; and (3) the Paleozoic basin remnants of the

Afligidos, Santa Br??gida, Curituba and Tacarutu formations, composed of sandstone,

siltstone, arkose, mudstone and conglomerate (Santos et al., 1988 a; b).

Despite the common acceptance of a post-rift setting for the Marizal Formation, the

tectonic setting of this unit is not well understood. During the 1980’s, the Marizal

Formation was interpreted as the erosional product of the remnant topography following

the end of rifting, in a simple shear tectonic context (sensu Wernicke, 1985), with no

thermal post-rift phase overlying the syn-rift deposits of the Tucano Basin (e.g. Netto

Oliveira, 1985; Ussami et al., 1986; Magnavita Cupertino, 1988; Milani Davison,

1988). Subsequently, the Marizal Formation was interpreted as the erosional remnant of

a thick sedimentary pile related to a thermal post-rift phase, after pure shear extensional

deformation (Magnavita et al., 1994). The deposition of thick thermal post-rift deposits,

presently eroded, was proposed on the basis of numerical modeling, vitrinite reflectance

data (Magnavita et al., 1994) and apatite fission track analysis (Japsen et al., 2012).

Nonetheless, the inclusion of the Marizal Formation deposits in the thermal subsidence

phase is controversial. It is based on (i) the local and poorly described superposition of

basement rocks beyond the footwall limits of the rift, in the Northern Tucano sub-basin

and in the Jatoba? Basin (e.g. Magnavita et al., 1994), (ii) the supposed contrasting

deformational styles preserved in the Marizal Formation and in the underlying Sa?o

Sebastia?o Formation (Destro et al., 2003), and (iii) the locally angular character for the

erosional (and supposedly regional) unconformity that bounds both units.

3. METHODS

Provenance data was collected in conglomerate and conglomeratic sandstone, coupled

with paleocurrent analysis. The collected data constrains the areal expression (in exposed

sections of pebbles) of each source rock in the analyzed sites, which was obtained through

the identification and classification of 300 clasts (pebble and cobble) per site and the

annotation of clast area (Table 1 – textbfAnexos). The area was obtained by measurement

of the lengths of the two main axes of every clast bigger than 0.5 cm, thus excluding grains

that could represent single mineral phases of coarse grained source rocks, which would

result in non-diagnostic source rock data. The area assessment approach was chosen to

avoid a possible bias due to the dependency between clast size and lithotype. Another

approach that can avoid such effect is the record of the volume of each lithology (e.g.



120

Ibbeken Schleyer, 1991; Du?rr, 1996), and although it can provide more precise provenance

data, the determination of the volume of each clast in lithified deposits is not practical.

The provenance compositional data set obtained in the field typically has zero values

(Table 2 – Anexos), which requires the substitution in order to perform multivariate

statistical analysis. To do so, Multiplicative Replacement Strategy (Mart??n-Fernandez et

al., 2003) was applied in each site sample, in order to preserve the covariance structure

within the replaced data set. However, instead of replacing the zero values by a value

equivalent to 65 % of the detection limit, as proposed by Mart??n-Fernandez et al. (2003)

and Palarea-Albaladejo et al. (2007), the zero values were replaced with the greatest value

indistinguishable from zero for the sample error in each site sample (Table 2 and Table 3

– Anexos). After that, the data sets were normalized (Table 4 – Anexos) and submitted

to Centered Log-Ratio transformation (Pawlowsky-Glahn Egozcue, 2006), so to stretch

the compositional data set to an unclosed data range (Table 5 – Anenos).

The provenance data was obtained in 44 outcrops, summing up more than 10,000 clasts

from both units. Nineteen sites of the Marizal Formation were analyzed, distributed over

the central and northern Tucano sub-basins, as well as twenty two sites of the Sa?o Sebastia?o

Formation, mostly located at the Vaza Barris transfer zone (Fig. 6.3). Additionally, three

sites of alluvial fan deposits were analyzed, which could be either lateral to the Marizal

Formation or to the syn-rift deposits (Santos et al., 2010), located at the eastern Central

Tucano sub-basin margin. Each clast was classified according to lithotype in the field, and

a second classification in five major groups was performed later, in order to identify major

differences in source areas at each site. These major groups are plutonic rocks, acid volcanic

rocks, basic and metabasic rocks, low grade metamorphic rocks and lithologies resistant

to weathering, which comprehend quartzite, vein quartz, chert, chalcedony, silexite, and

quartz mylonite. Basic statistical analysis and identification of meaningful indexes were

performed using both classifications.

Paleocurrent data were acquired from 30 outcrops of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation

and 16 sites of the Marizal Formation, distributed over the Central and Northern Tucano

sub-basins, summing up more than 1,500 individual measurements. The paleocurrent data

was collected mostly from trough and tabular cross bedding and locally from climbing

ripples, in fluvial and eolian deposits. The measured data were distributed in 15 classes

for each station, considering the facies associations, and rose diagrams were obtained using

the program Openstereo (Grohmann Campanha, 2010).



121

4. RESULTS

4.1 Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation

4.1.1 Pebble and cobble compositional data

Clast compositional data (pebble and cobble grain-size, Table 4 – Anexos) for the Sa?o

Sebastia?o Formation reveal that the three most representative lithotypes in area are vein

quartz (average of 64.06%), quartzite (average of 14.82%) and granite (average of 7.03%),

while other lithotypes are much less significant (all below 7%), which include chalcedony,

sandstone, schist, phyllite, mylonitic granite, siltstone, limestone, quartz mylonite, acid

volcanics, silexite and feldspar (Fig. 35).

Figura 35. Amount of lithotypes classes on each counting site of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation.

The distribution of these lithotypes per site is homogeneous through the basin, with

the exception of two outcrops (TUC 73 and TUC 74) which show a larger contribution of

mylonitic granite and limestone due to the local influence of basin-border basement rocks.

Thus, the comparison of lithotype groups shows that the resistant to weathering class

is by far the most significant (average of 83.22%), followed by plutonic rocks (10.67%),

sedimentary rocks (3.82%), low grade metamorphic rocks (2.07%) and acid volcanic rocks

(0.22%) (Fig. 36).

The map distribution of clast composition shows that sites from the margins of the

basin are poorer in resistant to weathering clasts (70% of the samples show less than 85%

of this group) than the ones at the center of the basin (all samples show more than 85%



122

Figura 36. Amount of grouped lithotypes in the alluvial fans, Sa?o Sebastia?o and Marizal formations.

of this class) (Fig. 37). Despite the spatial variation, clast composition does not vary

significantly with the stratigraphic position of the samples (Fig 38).

4.1.2 Paleocurrent Data

The mean paleocurrent obtained from the fluvial deposits of the Sa?o Sebastia?o

Formation points southwards, although there is some variation according to the facies

and the position where data was collected. Towards the west and southwest of Central

Tucano Basin, near the western basin border, subaqueous dune and ripple cross-bedding

point to a southeastward flow, whilst at all other sites, paleoflow is consistent towards

the south (Fig. 39). Complementary, five sites of eolian deposits, apparently coeval to

fluvial bars, were assessed. Three of those are located at the northwestern area of the

Central Tucano sub-basin, where a more than 200 m thick succession of eolian deposits

is exposed. These deposits are mainly fine to medium sandstone with more than 10 m

thick cross-sets, recording east-southeastward paleowinds. Data from two other outcrops,

interpreted as eolian dune field deposits from the northernmost part of the Tucano basin,

revealed opposite directions of paleowinds, towards the west (Fig. 39).

4.2.1 Pebble and Cobble Compositional Data

The statistical analysis of clast lithotypes from the Marizal Formation indicates five

major lithotypes, in order of magnitude: sandstone (average of 28.5%), vein quartz

(average of 19.25%), granite (average of 18.02%), quartzite (average of 11.91%), and

mylonitic granite (average of 6.57%). Other, less common, lithotypes are siltstone, phyllite,

schist, limestone, acid volcanics, quartz mylonite, silexite, aplite, basalt, conglomerate,

calcarenite, coal, leucocratic granite and metabasic rocks (Fig. 40).

The multivariate analysis of lithotype groups reveals the major difference between the

Sa?o Sebastia?o and the Marizal formations, as the latter shows more varied composition

and an average of only 31.76% of the resistant to weathering class, with 82% of the

sites showing less than 50% of clasts resistant to weathering. The sedimentary rocks

class is the most abundant (average of 34.15%), and plutonic rocks are also substantial

(average of 25.71%). On the other hand, low grade metamorphic rocks (average of 5.88%),

acid volcanics (average of 1.83%) and metabasic rocks (average of 0.68%) are much less

significant.

Spatial distribution of clast composition reveals similarities between the alluvial fan

deposits of the eastern Central Tucano sub-basin and a group of sites of the Marizal

Formation in the nearby area. This is evident in the cross-plot of the two Principal

Components (PC) for both units, due to the contribution of sandstone, siltstone, limestone

and acid volcanics (Fig. 41) in both the alluvial fans and in the nearby Marizal Formation

deposits (Fig. 42).

Figura 40. Frequency of lithotype classes on each analyzed site of the alluvial fan deposits and the Marizal

4.2.2 Paleocurrent Data

Figura 41. Results of Principal Component Analysis of pebbles and cobbles from the Marizal Formation

The paleocurrent analysis of the Marizal Formation (Fig. 42) resulted in the distinction

of two major trends of paleoflow. The first one, which has mean paleocurrent towards

the south, can be related to an axial fluvial system, as it follows the N-S trend of basin

geometry. In turn, the second trend has paleocurrents towards west-southwest, mostly from

sites closer to the east basin border, suggesting a tributary fluvial system transverse to the

basin axis. Additionally, local eolian deposits in the Marizal Formation were analyzed,

which show paleowinds towards the northeast and the east, contrasting with the data

recorded in the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation.

4.3 Alluvial Fan Deposits

Alluvial fan deposits in the eastern Central Tucano Basin show no clear stratigraphic

relationship with either the Marizal or the Sa?o Sebastia?o formations. Clast composition,

nevertheless, is similar to nearby deposits of the Marizal Formation (Fig. 43), with an

average of 45.23% of sedimentary rocks, 25.04% of resistant to weathering class, 21.39% of

low grade metamorphic rocks, 7,86% of plutonic rocks and 0.48% of basic and metabasic

rocks. The contribution of limestone is substantial (average of 26.78%), which is then

followed by quartzite (average of 23.32%), sandstone (17.04%), mica schist (13.16%) and

granite (7.62%).

4.4 Tectonic Setting of the Marizal Formation

The Marizal Formation is currently interpreted as the erosional remnant of a thick

post-rift succession attributed to thermal subsidence (e.g. Magnavita et al., 1994).

This interpretation relies on the following assertions: (i) the unit overlies a regional

unconformity, known as the pre-Upper Aptian unconformity, interpreted as related to

the break-up between South America and Africa and recognized in all cretaceous marginal

basins of the Central South Atlantic; (ii) it supposedly overlies the footwall basin border

in the Northern Tucano and Jatoba? basins; and (iii) it lacks deformational features that

are abundant in the syn-rift deposits.

During the Lower Aptian most of the Central South Atlantic cretaceous marginal

basins were filled by continental deposits, with sparse marine incursions, marking the

end of the rift phase. At this time, an eastward migration of the approximately NE

striking master fault zones is widely recognized in the eastern Brazilian margin, together

with the consequent uplift of the western half grabens filled by continental deposits. The

erosional surface developed over these uplifted areas gave rise to the so called pre-Upper

Aptian unconformity. The successions overlying this unconformity usually present a greater

proportion of marine sediments, with the continental deposits restricted to proximal

areas, and are less affected by tectonic deformation. Therefore, the Upper Aptian in

the eastern Brazilian margin is related to a regional post-rift tectonic phase, except

for the north-easternmost basins of Alagoas and Pernambuco-Para??ba (PE-PB), where

syn-tectonic conglomerates are laterally equivalent to evaporites, and rift phase tectonic

activity is interpreted until the Albian (e.g. Dias, 2005).

Considering the above described scenario, it is probable that the RTJ rift was, at

least in part, subject to the same tectonic regime during the Upper Aptian as the nearby

Alagoas and PE-PB basins, which is similar to that of the previous regional syn-rift phase.

The spatial distribution of the Marizal Formation beyond the footwall limits of the rift is

mentioned in the literature, without detailed descriptions (e.g. Magnavita et al., 1994),

is local and restricted to the Northern Tucano and Jatoba? basins. In the Central and

Southern Tucano, and in the Reco?ncavo Basin the unit occurs within the rift limits.

Although this virtual coincidence of limits of exposure between the Sa?o Sebastia?o and

the Marizal formations, the amount of deformational features preserved in both units have

been used as argument for the interpretation of the distinct tectonic phases. The relatively

common occurrence of faults, folds and extensive convolute beds in the Sa?o Sebastia?o

Formation, opposed to the apparent lack of structural and syn-depositional deformation



130

Figura 44. Differences between Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation (A) and Marizal Formation (B) deformed
beds. (A) Convolute bedding (highlighted by inclined white arrows) within 3.5 meter thick cross-bedded
sandstones in the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation. Vertical arrow on the right shows 1.75 meter tall person for
scale; (B) Overturned cross-strata on 0.5 meter thick medium to coarse grained sandstone beds of the
Marizal Formation.



131

in the Marizal Formation (e.g. Destro et al., 2003), is one of the main arguments for the

interpretation of an active tectonic setting with mechanical subsidence for the former and

a quiescent, post-rift setting with thermal subsidence for the latter (Magnavita et al., 1994;

Magnavita et al., 2003). There is indeed a difference in the deformational styles of the Sa?o

Sebastia?o and Marizal Formations, with syn-depositional deformation being much more

conspicuous in the former unit than in the latter. The Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation deposits

often display meter-scale thick, sharp based and toped, convolute beds, laterally continuous

for dozens of meters (Fig. 44), whereas convolute beds in the Marizal Formation are

less frequent, less laterally continuous, thinner and generally associated with overturned

cross-strata (Fig. 44B). In this way, the syn-depositional deformation preserved in the

Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation presents the main diagnostic criteria for the interpretation of

seismites (e.g. Owen et al., 2011; Owen Moretti, 2011), whereas the Marizal Formation

syn-sedimentary deformational features are probably related to current shear stress during

intense floods (e.g. Røe Hermansen, 2006).

Figura 45. (A) Tectonic deformation (normal fault) affecting the Marizal Formation at the Northern
Tucano Basin. (B) Zoom of the square on the left.

Nevertheless, despite the occurrence of faults interpreted from subsurface data (e.g.

Magnavita et al., 1994), it is important to note that the major exposed tectonic

deformational features of the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation are restricted to areas where the

Marizal Formation deposits were completely removed by erosion, such as those in and

adjacent to the Vaza-Barris and Itapicuru river valleys (Fig. 6.3). These areas coincide with

the transference zones between the three sub-basins of the Tucano Rift. Moreover, there are

abundant minor faults with normal to oblique centimeter-scale displacements in the Marizal



132

Formation in areas where the underlying deposits (Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation) present the

same kind of structural deformation. Examples preserved in the Marizal Formation are

reported from the Reco?ncavo Basin (Lima Vilas Boas, 2000) and can also be observed in

the Northern Tucano sub-basin (Fig. 45). Therefore, tectonic activation and mechanical

subsidence during the deposition of the Marizal formation cannot be ruled out.

5. DISCUSSION

The integration of pebble composition and paleocurrent data with the evidence of

tectonic deformation in the Marizal and Sa?o Sebastia?o formations suggests a major change

in source areas between the Neocomian and the Aptian, probably related to the tectonic

evolution of the region. The high content in resistant to weathering clasts in the Sa?o

Sebastia?o Formation is probably related to polycyclic reworking of sediment, pointing the

Paleozoic sedimentary successions, in which conglomerates and pebbly sandstones rich in

vein quartz are frequent, as a major source. Preserved areas of these Paleozoic Successions

are found at the basin borders, and the presence of continuous Paleozoic units below the rift

deposits suggests that the basin shoulders where covered by these units at least during the

early rift phase (Fig. 46A). The identified higher content in clasts resistant to weathering

at the basin center, if compared to the basin margin deposits, combined to an average axial

fluvial flow towards the south, suggest that transverse drainage systems incised down to the

basement, and that distal areas further north contributed with great amounts of polycyclic

clasts. That scenario is in agreement with the hypothesis that, during the Cretaceous,

the Paleozoic successions of the Parnaiba Basin (with modern exposures 500 km to the

northwest) were continuous with the Paleozoic deposits in the vicinity of the RTJ rift.

The abrupt decrease in the proportion of polycyclic clasts in the Marizal Formation

points to a larger contribution of local sources from the basement rocks, as a result of

the denudation of the Paleozoic succession on the basin shoulders and the exposure of

the Sergipana belt sedimentary, volcanic and metasedimentary rocks. This hypothesis

suggests tectonic activity during the deposition of the Marizal Formation, since the

continuous denudation of an hypothetical tectonically inactive relief reminiscent of the

syn-rift phase would result in gradual change in the clast composition, rather than the

observed abrupt change in provenance. Moreover, the tectonic uplift of the basement

during the deposition of the Marizal Formation could explain the sharp decrease in the

contribution of Paleozoic sedimentary sources, through the shift of the watershed to a

position closer to the basin margin, leaving the remaining exposures of Paleozoic rocks



133

between the Sa?o Sebastia?o (A) and the Marizal Formations (B) in the Tucano Basin. A- During the main

134

behind it (Fig. 46B). Additionally, the correlation of the alluvial fan deposits of the

eastern Central Tucano sub-basin with the Marizal Formation favors the hypothesis of

tectonic activity, indicating the presence of a local scarp affecting the Sergipana belt rocks.

The recognition of normal and oblique faults affecting the Marizal formation corroborate

the model.

6. CONCLUSIONS

Composition of pebbles and cobbles in the Sa?o Sebastia?o and Marizal formations of

the Tucano Basin (Northeastern Brazil) shows an abrupt change in maturity between the

Barremian and the Aptian. The Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation (Neocomian to Barremian) is

characterized by a dominance of pebbles resistant to weathering, which can be explained

as polycyclic reworking of Paleozoic sedimentary successions. The Marizal Formation

(Aptian), on its turn, is characterized by a larger variability in the composition of pebbles

and cobbles, with the predominance of clasts from the precambrian basement of the basin.

This abrupt shift in provenance suggests the activation of the basin border normal faults

during the deposition of the Marizal Formation, resulting in the uplift of the basement.

The proposed model considers the local contribution from the rift shoulders as the

most important source of coarse-grained clasts for both units. The presence of paleozoic

successions containing polycyclic pebbles resistant to weathering on the basin shoulders

during the Neocomian and the Barremian could account for the high content of these clasts

in the Sa?o Sebastia?o Formation. Nevertheless, some incision of the underlying precambrian

basement is indicated by the higher content of basement rocks as pebbles near the basin

borders. This also suggests that the axial river system, which flowed towards the south

according to the paleocurrent data, was richer in clasts resistant to weathering, indicating

the denudation of paleozoic successions also to the north.

The Marizal Formation, on the other hand, show a much lower content of these

polycyclic clasts, even tough the paleocurrent data points to the continuity of the paleoflow

towards the south, which suggests the evolution of the same drainage system. A possible

model to explain this abrupt change in pebble and cobble composition includes the

activation of the basin border faults after the erosional retreat of the fault scarps that

affected the paleozoic successions during the Neocomian and the Barremian. This would

lead to the uplift of the precambrian basement on the basin shoulders, with the denudation

of the paleozoic successions taking place behind the uplifted watershed. A clear correlation

between the composition of pebbles from fault-scarp derived alluvial fan deposits found in



135

the eastern Central Tucano sub-basin and the sites of Marizal Formation near that area

corroborate the model, as do the presence of normal and oblique faults affecting the Marizal

Formation in the Northern Tucano sub-basin.

The recognition of an aptian extensional activation has implications for the tectonic

evolution of Eastern South America during the Early Cretaceous, since the unconformity

between the Sa?o Sebastia?o and the Marizal formations has been traditionally considered

as the local evidence of the end of regional rifting and inversion of the regional stress field

to a compressional one, due to the onset of ridge push and thermal subsidence in the

South Atlantic. Nonetheless, the data presented here suggest that, at least part of the

RTJ was subject to rifting during the deposition of the Marizal Formation in the Aptian

as previously interpreted for the northernmost tip of the Central South Atlantic rift system

north of the Sergipe – Alagoas Basin.

Additionally, the proposed model has important implications for the interpretation of

abrupt changes in maturity in rift basin successions, since similar results are expected where

activation of basin border faults occurs after the erosional retreat of scarps developed in

older sedimentary or volcanic units.

7. Discussa?o

As formac?o?es Sa?o Sebastia?o e Marizal representam sistemas fluviais (e.g. Viana et al.,

1971; Caixeta et al., 1994; Magnavita et al., 2003; Costa et al., 2007) depositados durante

a deformac?a?o distensiva que condicionou o sistema de riftes Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba?

(RTJ) entre o Neocomiano e o Aptiano. A arquitetura deposicional da sucessa?o fluvial da

Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte apresenta forte controle

tecto?nico. Enquanto a leste, na a?rea de maior taxa de subside?ncia (e.g. Magnavita, 1996),

pro?ximo a? falha de borda e ao Baixo de C??cero Dantas, os depo?sitos foram gerados a partir

de um estilo fluvial dominado por carga mista, caracterizado pela intercalac?a?o de barras

arenosas e sedimentos de granulac?a?o fina, caracter??sticas de ambientes localizados ale?m

das margens do canal principal (overbank areas ); afastando-se do depocentro em direc?a?o

a a?reas de menor subside?ncia sobre a zona de transfere?ncia do Vaza Barris, predominam

macroformas e mesoformas arenosas com espessuras e continuidade lateral muito maiores,

constituindo corpos arenosos dominados por fa?cies e arquiteturas de cinturo?es de canais.

Na zona de transfere?ncia do Vaza Barris, onde esta? localizada a a?rea de menor

subside?ncia, o sistema fluvial da Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o apresenta dois tipos diferentes de

estratificac?a?o cruzada composta: uma relacionada a barras unita?rias ou dunas grandes

compostas (Unit Bars or large compound dunes – AE1) e outra relacionada a barras

compostas de acre?scimo a jusante (Downstream accretion compound bars – AE2), cujas

dimenso?es sa?o escaladas com a largura do canal durante a sua formac?a?o. A superf??cie

de superimposic?a?o das barras unita?rias e de dunas grandes compostas pode ocorrer como

limites de se?rie simples, mas a variac?a?o lateral de frentes de dunas (foreset) de grande escala

para estratos cruzados compostos de menor escala implica em que a mesma superf??cie seja

tanto um limite de uma se?rie de grande porte como uma superf??cie limitante de estratos

cruzados compostos (Figura 13 - artigo 1). Neste sentido, as reativac?o?es e mudanc?as no

tamanho dos gra?os e na orientac?a?o de estruturas sedimentares induzidas por variac?o?es na

descarga de a?gua podem ser confundidas com incrementos sobre a macroforma (Figuras

11 e 12 – artigo 1). Assim, as barras unita?rias ou dunas grandes (>1 m de espessura

preservada de estratos cruzados) evoluem para dunas compostas e registram eventos de

enchentes de forma parecida com a que ocorre nas barras compostas, apesar de serem

escaladas com a profundidade da la?mina d’a?gua e portanto muito menores do que as barras

compostas do mesmo sistema. Com isso, pode-se afirmar que a classificac?a?o hiera?rquica

de superf??cies limitantes em depo?sitos de rios de grandes dimenso?es mostra um grau de

complexidade grande. Isso dificulta a utilizac?a?o de superf??cies limitantes de acordo com



141

a classificac?a?o hiera?rquica temporal, como a proposta por Miall (1996), tendo-se optado

por uma designac?a?o alternativa de superf??cies atrave?s de termos que refletem sua origem

(Tabelas 1 e 2 – artigo 1), baseada na abordagem adotada para depo?sitos eo?licos (e.g.

Mountney, 2006). Deve-se notar que a atribuic?a?o de significados temporais para os

elementos arquiteturais como proposto por Miall (1996) e? tambe?m discut??vel no caso de

depo?sitos de rios grandes, uma vez que barras com escala quilome?trica podem ser formadas

no intervalo de tempo originalmente atribu??do a incrementos de escala me?trica, como ciclos

sazonais e de poucos anos relacionados a grandes enchentes (e.g. Ashworth et al., 2000).

Em rios grandes, algumas mesoformas (barras unita?rias e dunas grandes) podem ser da

mesma escala de macroformas (barras compostas de acre?scimo a jusante) de rios pequenos.

Como as dimenso?es das formas de leito sa?o proporcionais a? profundidade da la?mina

d’a?gua, a espessura preservada das mesoformas e? uma das melhores evide?ncias para a

interpretac?a?o de depo?sitos gerados a partir de rios de grandes proporc?o?es (e.g. Miall, 2006;

Fielding et al., 2007). De maneira similar, Miall & Jones (2003) distinguiram depo?sitos de

barras de acre?scimo a jusante do elemento de duna compostas na sucessa?o do Hawkesbury

Sandstone, (sudeste da Austra?lia), interpretada como produto de um sistema fluvial de

grandes proporc?o?es.

Na Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o, estratos cruzados de escala me?trica interpretados como

depo?sitos de barras unita?rias e dunas compostas grandes constituem o principal elemento

para interpretar o predom??nio de canais com va?rios metros de profundidade. Estes sa?o

diferenciados dos depo?sitos de barras compostas de acre?scimo a jusante devido a sua

transic?a?o lateral para frentes de dunas (foresets) com se?ries de ate? cinco metros de

espessura, que por sua vez sa?o limitadas por superf??cies de cavalgamento de baixo a?ngulo

(unit bars and large compound dunes superimposition surface (superf??cie 5)), o que sugere

sua origem como produto do empilhamento de formas de leito perio?dicas ou semiperio?dicas.

Esta u?ltima caracter??stica e? fundamental para separar barras unita?rias e dunas grandes de

barras compostas, ja? que faces de avalanche tambe?m podem ocorrer em depo?sitos de barras

compostas (e.g. Best et al., 2003) que, no entanto, por serem formas na?o-perio?dicas, na?o

cavalgam sistematicamente outras barras.

Na a?rea onde ocorrem as maiores taxas de subside?ncia da bacia, a porc?a?o superior da

Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o foi interpretada como um sistema fluvial de carga mista, dominado

por barras de acre?scimo a jusante, intercalada com depo?sitos de plan??cies de inundac?a?o.

A ocorre?ncia frequente de camadas convolutas indica provavelmente atividade s??smica,

interpretac?a?o consistente com o contexto sin-rifte em que a sucessa?o esta? inserida.



142

Considerando que as proporc?o?es de plan??cies de inundac?a?o e de espessura de sucesso?es

de topo de barra sa?o maiores pro?ximo a borda leste da Sub-Bacia Tucano Central do

que nas a?reas a oeste, foi proposto um modelo integrador da arquitetura fluvial e do

modelo tecto?nico da fase sin-rifte. Sugere-se que o principal controle deposicional tenha

sido o contexto tecto?nico local, no qual a ocorre?ncia de maiores taxas de gerac?a?o de espac?o

de acomodac?a?o na a?rea de ma?xima subside?ncia pode ter contribu??do para o aumento da

preservac?a?o de depo?sitos ale?m das margens do canal principal. Ale?m disso, as altas taxas

de gerac?a?o de espac?o de acomodac?a?o podem tambe?m ter sido responsa?veis pela maior

preservac?a?o de partes rasas das barras fluviais, sobre as quais foram preservados pequenos

depo?sitos de lagos, de dunas geradas por retrabalhamento eo?lico e de canais pequenos.

Em relac?a?o ao estilo do canal presente nesta a?rea da bacia, ressalta-se o predom??nio de

barras de acre?scimo a jusante, o que e? sugestivo de canais entrelac?ados de baixa sinuosidade

do elemento crevasse splay (AE7) em forma de cunha, com mergulho paralelo ao fluxo

principal das barras (AE2), sugere que localmente alguns canais dessa a?rea podem ter tido

promovida pela distribuic?a?o desigual das taxas de subside?ncia em gra?bens assime?tricos,

o que por sua vez pode levar a variac?o?es morfolo?gicas nos estilos fluviais (e.g. Alexander

entrelac?ado principal, como demonstrado por Bridge (2003) em sistemas fluviais modernos.

As diferenc?as marcantes entre a arquitetura da Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o pro?xima ao

depocentro do sistema de riftes Reco?ncavo-Tucano-Jatoba? e na a?rea central da zona de

dos afloramentos estudados nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte (Figura 10) na?o

Os principais controles esperados para zonas de transfere?ncia sa?o o aporte de sistemas

fluviais transversais ao eixo da bacia nessas zonas e/ou sua atuac?a?o como barreira

Sa?o Sebastia?o indicam migrac?a?o sistema?tica de meso e macroformas para sul, corroborando

o posicionamento axial do sistema fluvial, sem evide?ncias de contribuic?o?es transversais

associadas a? Zona de Transfere?ncia do Vaza-Barris. Mesmo podendo influenciar a



143

distribuic?a?o de gradientes locais, o papel desse alto estrutural como barreira topogra?fica

De acordo com esta hipo?tese, a Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o teria progradado sobre a zona de

transfere?ncia, sem modificac?o?es na arquitetura dos depo?sitos.

A integrac?a?o de dados composicionais de clastos e de paleocorrentes com as evide?ncias

144

da bacia, deixando as exposic?o?es remanescentes daquelas sucesso?es sedimentares antigas

8. Concluso?es

A ana?lise da arquitetura deposicional de afloramentos de sucesso?es fluviais da Formac?a?o

Sa?o Sebastia?o (Neocomiano a Barremiano) nas Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte,

integrada a ana?lises de paleocorrentes e provenie?ncia de seixos, levaram ao estabelecimento

de modelos de fa?cies para os sistemas fluviais e infere?ncias sobre a evoluc?a?o das a?reas fonte

e os controles tecto?nicos na distribuic?a?o dos diferentes tipos de sistemas reconhecidos.

A Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o na porc?a?o central da Sub-Bacia Tucano Central e Norte foi

interpretada como produto de sistemas fluviais predominantemente arenosos, semelhantes

a rios entrelac?ados, e, na porc?a?o leste da Sub-Bacia Tucano Central, como produto de

sistemas fluviais de carga mista.

Entre as Sub-Bacias Tucano Central e Norte, a?rea fortemente afetada pela Zona de

Transfere?ncia do Vaza-Barris, foram interpretados cinco elementos arquiteturais: barras

unita?rias ou dunas grandes e compostas (EA1), barras de acre?scimo a? jusante (EA2),

preenchimento de canais pequenos (EA3), dunas eo?licas (EA4) e depo?sitos de topo de

barras (EA5). Dentre todos, predominam os elementos de barras de acre?scimo a? jusante e

de barras unita?rias ou dunas grandes e compostas. A distinc?a?o entre esses dois elementos

foi baseada na identificac?a?o de frentes de avalanche com se?ries de grande escala (ate? 5

m de espessura) que passam lateralmente para se?ries de estratificac?a?o cruzada composta

e na presenc?a de superf??cies de superimposic?a?o com pequeno a?ngulo de cavalgamento

entre as dunas compostas. A abunda?ncia do elemento de barras unita?rias ou dunas

grandes e compostas e? considerada como evide?ncia da presenc?a de canais profundos, o

que caracteriza um sistema de rio de grandes proporc?o?es. A menor freque?ncia de fa?cies

pel??ticas, organizadas como lentes, sugere a presenc?a de ambientes mais rasos no topo das

barras, na?o necessariamente relacionados ao desenvolvimento de plan??cies de inundac?a?o

ale?m das margens do canal. A identificac?a?o do elemento proposto como barras unita?rias

ou dunas grandes e compostas, e sua distinc?a?o de depo?sitos de barras de acre?scimo a

jusante, podem ser u?teis na descric?a?o e interpretac?a?o da arquitetura de depo?sitos de rios

de grandes proporc?o?es.

Na porc?a?o leste da bacia, junto ao Baixo de C??cero Dantas, onde ocorrem as mais

elevadas taxas de subside?ncia do rift RTJ, foram interpretados os elementos de canal

EA1, barras unita?rias e dunas compostas grandes, (Unit bars and Large compound dunes ),

EA2, barras de acre?scimo a? jusante (Downstream accretion bar ) e EA3, preenchimento

de canal pequeno (Minor channel fills ) e os elementos originados em a?reas ale?m das

margens do canal principal EA4, dunas eo?licas (Eolian Dunes ), EA5, plan??cie ou bacias de



146

inundac?a?o (Floodplain fines ), EA6, canal abandonado (Abandoned channel ), e EA7, leque

de rompimento de dique marginal (Crevasse splay ). A interac?a?o entre esses elementos

sugere um contexto fluvial de carga mista, dominado pela alterna?ncia de deposic?a?o

de barras fluviais arenosas que migravam para sul e de deposic?a?o por decantac?a?o em

ambientes ale?m das margens do canal principal. Como forma de explicar esta relac?a?o

espacial, sugere-se que o espac?o de acomodac?a?o mais elevado teria contribu??do para a

preservac?a?o de ambientes como plan??cies de inundac?a?o, possibilitando a preservac?a?o de

sucesso?es dominadas por processos de decantac?a?o, parcialmente retrabalhadas por sistemas

eo?licos. Este controle tecto?nico pode indicar que o sistema deposicional local sofreu forte

influencia das elevadas taxas de subside?ncia, que sa?o as maiores do sistema RTJ, onde

esta?o preservados 14 km de sucesso?es depositadas durante o esta?gio sin-rifte.

A comparac?a?o entre clastos de depo?sitos aluviais das formac?o?es Sa?o Sebastia?o e Marizal,

que sobrepo?e a primeira por discorda?ncia regional, revelou uma mudanc?a abrupta de

maturidade entre as unidades. A Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o (Neocomiano ate? Barremiano)

e? caracterizada pelo predom??nio de clastos resistentes ao intemperismo, o que pode

ser explicado pelo retrabalhamento polic??clico de sucesso?es sedimentares paleozoicas e

mesozoicas. A Formac?a?o Marizal (Aptiano), em contrapartida, e? caracterizada por

uma grande variedade composicional de seixos e calhaus, com predom??nio de clastos do

embasamento Pre?-Cambriano da bacia. Esta mudanc?a abrupta na provenie?ncia sugere

a ativac?a?o de falhas normais localizadas nas bordas da bacia durante a deposic?a?o da

Formac?a?o Marizal, resultando no soerguimento do embasamento.

O modelo proposto leva em conta a contribuic?a?o de fontes locais presentes nas ombreiras

do rifte como mais relevantes para provenie?ncia dos seixos e calhaus em ambas unidades.

A presenc?a de sucesso?es paleozoicas e mesozoicas contendo seixos polic??clicos de clastos

resistentes ao intemperismo nas ombreiras da bacia durante os per??odos Neocomiano e

Barremiano pode ter causado o predom??nio destes clastos para a Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o.

Contudo, a existe?ncia de inciso?es locais ate? o n??vel do embasamento pre?-cambriano deve

ser considerada, devido ao maior conteu?do de clastos de rochas do embasamento nessa

unidade estar localizado em a?reas pro?ximas as bordas da bacia. Isto sugere ainda que o

sistema fluvial axial, que flu??a para sul de acordo com os dados de paleocorrente, era mais

rico em clastos resistentes ao intemperismo, indicando a denudac?a?o de fontes sedimentares

paleozoicas tambe?m a norte da bacia.

Por outro lado, a Formac?a?o Marizal apresenta um conteu?do bem menor de clastos

polic??clicos, embora os dados de paleocorrentes apontem para paleofluxos cont??nuos de



147

norte para sul, o que sugere a evoluc?a?o de um mesmo sistema de drenagem. Um

modelo poss??vel que explicaria esta mudanc?a abrupta da composic?a?o de clastos inclui a

ativac?a?o de falhas de borda apo?s o recuo erosivo das escarpas de falha que afetaram as

sucesso?es paleozoicas e mesozoicas durante o Neocomiano e o Barremiano. Isto levaria

ao soerguimento do embasamento pre?-cambriano ate? o n??vel das ombreiras da bacia, a

medida em que as sucesso?es mesozoicas e paleozoicas fossem denudadas e passassem a

clastos provenientes dos depo?sitos de leques aluviais localizados na borda leste da sub-bacia

Tucano central e os s??tios da Formac?a?o Marizal pro?ximos corroboram o modelo de ativac?a?o

tecto?nica no Aptiano, assim como a presenc?a de falhas normais e obl??quas que afetam a

Formac?a?o Marizal na sub-bacia Tucano Norte.

A identificac?a?o de atividade distensiva durante o Aptiano tem implicac?o?es para a

evoluc?a?o tecto?nica do leste da Ame?rica do Sul durante o Creta?ceo, pois a discorda?ncia entre

as formac?o?es Sa?o Sebastia?o e Marizal tem sido considerada como evide?ncia local do final da

ridge push e da subside?ncia te?rmica no Atla?ntico Sul. Entretanto, os dados apresentados

sugerem que pelo menos parte do rifte RTJ foi submetido ao processo de distensa?o durante a

deposic?a?o da Formac?a?o Marizal no Aptiano, como interpretado anteriormente para a bacia

de Sergipe – Alagoas. Ale?m disso, o modelo proposto tem implicac?o?es importantes para

a interpretac?a?o de variac?o?es abruptas na maturidade das sucesso?es rifte, ja? que resultados

similares sa?o esperados em situac?o?es de atividade das falhas de borda da bacia apo?s a

retrac?a?o erosiva das escarpas desenvolvidas em unidades vulca?nicas ou rochas sedimentares

Desta forma, o sistema fluvial da Formac?a?o Sa?o Sebastia?o pode ser caracterizado como

resultante da instalac?a?o de um rio de grandes proporc?o?es no eixo de uma das principais

bacias rift do Eocreta?ceo brasileiro. Esse sistema relaciona-se possivelmente a uma bacia

de captac?a?o regional, responsa?vel pela denudac?a?o de a?reas em soerguimento durante a

atividade tecto?nica distensiva no leste da Ame?rica do Sul. Apesar do grande fluxo de

maior preservac?a?o de fa?cies de plan??cies de inundac?a?o e topos de barras, resultante da

maior gerac?a?o de espac?o de acomodac?a?o e de eventos de avulsa?o mais frequentes. As

a?reas fonte desse sistema foram predominantemente sucesso?es sedimentares paleozoicas

e mesozoicas, presentes em toda regia?o e dominantes nas ombreiras da bacia ate? o



148

Barremiano. Reativac?a?o tecto?nica da bacia e soerguimento renovado das ombreiras apo?s
